column5: For each of the selected answers in Q1, please describe what responsibilities they have for LGBTQ+ DE&I in your organisation.
column6: Our Board is ultimately responsible for driving L&G's D&I agenda which includes embracing and progressing the LGBTQ+ agenda, and we have a dedicated Independent Non-Executive Director, Nilufer Von Bismarck OBE, who is the Designated Workforce Director responsible for engaging with employees and representing their views. Part of our Board's responsibilities are to hold our Group D&I Council to account for defining and implementing our global D&I strategy. Our Group D&I Council is chaired by Laura Mason, CEO, Private Markets and a member of our Group Management Committee. For us D&I goes beyond the traditional focus on “protected characteristics” such as age, ethnicity, sexual orientation, disability and gender identity. While these are very important indicators of what an individual’s perspective might be, we also think that every individual has unique circumstances and our Group D&I Council is accountable for understanding our employees perspectives as well as shaping our D&I agenda. To drive the delivery of our D&I agenda, our Group Head of Inclusion, Group Inclusion Partners and HR teams (Talent Acquisition, Engagement, Policy, Learning ﹠ Development) each play a part in implementing L&G's strategy. Each of our divisional CEOs (and members of our Group Executive Committee) have a proportion of their bonus awarded based on culture. Our annual "Culture Review" process is an in-depth assessment of the levels of inclusion across our business, where we look at diversity data, employee feedback and progress made against our stated D&I goals. Lastly, we have an active and engaged global employee network specifically for LGBTQ+ people and allies - Our "L&GBT+Allies" network. This network champions the voice and experience of LGBTQ+ colleagues, reaches out to community and society and drives our inclusive agenda forwards.
column9: For each of the selected stakeholder groups in Q3, please describe who they are and how they are measured against LGBTQ+ DE&I goals and objectives. Please confirm that you have the permission of the person referenced to use their name.
column10: Our Board is ultimately accountable for ensuring L&G is a diverse and inclusive place. On an annual basis, the Board publishes progress against our Group Diversity Policy which covers our commitments on D&I. On a quarterly basis the Board, via our Nominations & Corporate Governance Committee, receives progress updates from our Group D&I Council on issues and progress. - Our Group Executive Committee (C-Suite and Executive Management) are responsible for delivering against our internal and external D&I commitments. Our Group Execs each have 10% of their variable bonus attributed to their performance creating an inclusive culture. Our annual Culture Review process is undertaken as a bottom-up and top-down review of progress around culture, including on our aims to create a diverse workforce and inclusive workplace. - Our group and divisional D&I teams are targeted to deliver against their respective D&I plans as part of our regular performance review process. - As well as the regular performance review process, Line Managers are also assessed using colleague feedback from their teams. The data is captured using our "Voice" employee surveys (every 6months). We ask colleagues to provide feedback against a number of issues including inclusion, connection / belonging, speaking out and purposeful leadership. It's also worth acknowledging our view on targets. We want to see regular, progressive improvements in the diversity of our workforce. We won’t be setting outcome targets; instead we track progress against a baselines. This is for a number of reasons: - we recognise that our work to increase the diversity of our workforce and the inclusion of our workplace will never be done - it's a journey of continuous improvement. - It’s also because we have a diverse business. Hove, Cardiff, Chicago, Hong Kong, Singapore and London are very different places, and success will look slightly different for every business we run and every geography we operate in. - We also know that data about our employees is critical if we’re to understand the progress we’re making against our vision: we’ll only know how successful we’ve been when we understand the scale of the challenge we face. - What doesn’t change is our overall vision of a diverse workforce and an inclusive workplace. Our group-wide ambition is to deliver progressive improvement against a range of trackable data.
column13: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column14: We amplify voices of our LGBT+ employees and their allies not just around Pride but throughout the year on our internal communication channels (the Hub) and regular updates from senior leaders. For example, in 2024 we asked we asked a number of our LGBT+ colleagues to share their personal journeys and the collective significance of Pride month on our Intranet. We promote the events organised by our L&GBT+Allies Network across the group with the support of senior execs and have taken steps in 2024 to focus on the Allyship aspects of the network (e.g. our Allyship Unmasked: Inspiring Stories of Support event in May 2024 held in conjunction with LGBT Great and chaired by Michael Marks, the network’s senior sponsor). Other networks are also keen to partner up with L&GBT in organising family/parenting events (Family and Carers Network) and LGBT+ mental health events (Health&Wellbeing) and also recognise the challenges faced by LGBT+ individuals across the world (Culture Club). All employees have a Culture/D﹠I objective which is measured as part of the annual review process, additionally colleagues who support the LGBT agenda are recognised through the Chairman's awards, opportunities to attend LGBT+ awards, partake in mentoring and leadership development, educational and social events organised by the LGBT committee and funded by the business.
column17: For each of the selected responses in Q7, please describe what proactive actions have been taken in the last 12 months by individuals and the organisation.
column18: - We encouraged colleagues in leadership positions across multiple locations to participate in the LGBT Great mentoring programme as mentors and mentees, - We continue an approach for Reverse Mentoring in our insurance business with one of the pre-defined issues areas was regarding the LGBT+ experience. - We continue to invest in significant coaching provision of Line Managers and Leaders - designed to help them create inclusive environments in their teams, businesses and divisions. - The network has worked with senior leaders in a reverse mentoring capacity to share their challenges and to educate the leadership teams - Deon Pillay, previously a co-chair of our L&GBT network is now co-chair of The Legal & General Inclusion Team -We also partner with LGBT Great, Trans in the City, Just Like Us and Interinvest to ensure training, development and awareness of LGBT+ issues, language, allyship. - Senior Leaders and network colleagues continue to support other organisations, in their capacity as panellist and key notes: Diversity Project, LGBT Great, InterInvest, Just Like Us, The LGBTQ+ Insurance Network, Involve, and Pride
column25: For each of the selected options in Q3, please describe how your LGBTQ+ DE&I strategy addresses each option.
column26: Workforce planning, succession planning & promotion HR and business colleagues have access to our workforce data and use it as part of our Strategic Workforce Planning processes. HR have access to the data to identify and resolve issues around promotion. LGBTQ+ Talent Attraction/Recruitment Recruitment is a key lever for our Group-wide D&I strategy. Our Talent Acquisition teams work closely with external partners to attract diverse candidates for all roles including work experience and internships. We've also adopted a policy of blind CVs to reduce the risk of bias in our shortlisting and selection processes. Talent Retention In terms of Talent Retention and Learning & Development, we recognise our role as an inclusive employer is about creating opportunities for people to develop and acquire skills. We also recognise that the quality of Line Management across L&G is a key lever for us to improve productivity, inclusion and engagement. We're committed to offering all 1900 of our Line Managers the chance to improve knowledge and skills. Coupled with this programme is a range of focused learning interventions on topics such as inclusive leadership and inclusive management, better decisions, building diverse teams and inclusive ways of working. Learning & Development The L&GBT+ Network has a workstream dedicated to Learning & Development, which focuses on organising events and creating resources and programmes providing education on LGBTQ+ topics. In 2024 this workstream organised a several educational events utilising our relationships with our charity partners, added a number of educational resources to our network hub which can be accessed across the business, and launched a company wide Allyship training programme. Pay, rewards & benefits Staff are rewarded based on their end of year appraisal, objectives are linked to DEI, In addition colleagues championing LGBT+ diversity have received tickets to LGBT awards, enjoy company sponsored social networking and LGBT+ events together with Career development and mentoring opportunities. DE&I Data Capture / Analysis / KPIs At the heart of our Group-wide D&I approach is the data we ask our people to share. LGBT+ status and gender identity are two key pieces of data we ask employees to share. This data, along with a range of other "protected characteristics" is reported and tracked using our Group-wide D&I Dashboards. These dashboards allow us to track representation across the employee lifecycle - attraction, hiring / new joiners, promotions and leavers. We use this data in a number of ways: - our Group D&I Council reviews this data quarterly and invites our Divisional / Functional leadership teams to explain trends in their data - leadership teams receive the data monthly as part of their standard reporting - our Nominations Committee and Board will review extracts of the data on an annual basis to ensure we are delivering against our goals Communications Visibility is an important part of LGBTQ+ inclusion. Employee stories and testimonials from LGBTQ+ colleagues are shared both through internal L&G News communications and externally through a variety of channels including our website and LinkedIn. Procurement The procurement policy explicitly calls out discrimination on the basis of sexuality and or gender identity.

column33: For each of the selected options in Q6, please list the policy and provide supporting commentary. Please attach a copy of the policies.
column34: The following policies cover those ticked above and apply to all UK employees of companies in the Legal & General Group which are wholly owned by Legal & General and the policy attachments relate specifically to these. Diversity and inclusion policy: covers sexual orientation, gender identity and expression and trans (which includes transgender, non-binary and gender non-conforming) employees Dignity at work policy: covers bullying, harrassment and stalking to create a work environment free from harassment and bullying, where everyone is treated with dignity and respect – whatever their sexual orientation, gender identity and gender expression Family leave policy: this includes adoption, maternity, paternity and shared parental leave and is available regardless of sexual orientation, gender identity and gender expression Trans and non-binary policy: this is specifically aimed to recognise, support and understand an employees gender identity and gender expression. It includes a guide for trans employees and also one for colleagues of trans employees. We have a manager guide that is separate to the policy, to help them support a trans employee.

column45: How does your organisation utilise sexual orientation and gender identity diversity data to improve LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column46: The way we use sexual orientation and gender identity data to improve outcomes for LGBTQ+ people as well as support our wider DEI agenda, is ever evolving. - We have enacted improvements on how we collect DEI data removing the transgender option from gender identity question as this is not appropriate and instead have included the question asking "Is your current gender the same as the one identified at birth?" . The aim of this is to be more inclusive for our trans+ colleagues. - We continue to use this data throughout the employee lifecycle from attraction and hiring, through employee onboarding and then key milestones in an employee’s life with us at L&G. This may include promotion, mobility and when they ultimately choose to leave the firm. Having data at these stages in the employees journey delivers value for the firm because it allows us to identify hidden dynamics that may exist and may advantage / disadvantage certain groups. We don’t report these externally although we use the insight to shape our D&I work. For employees it gives comfort that we’re working hard to make L&G an open, inclusive employer.
column49: What campaigns, strategies or approaches has your organisation undertaken to improve comfort around disclosing self-ID DE&I data?
column50: For new joiners we have prompts within their onboarding journey to ensure their information is accurate. They are also auto enrolled into the Hive Intro to Inclusion learning. We have an annual Count Me In campaign where communications go out across the business to encourage employees to share this data with the business and we have recently made changes to the options within our HRMS to better reflect how gender identity is disclosed.
column53: How does your organisation target and attract LGBTQ+ talent?
column54: L&G careers website: Our new careers website includes employee testimonials and story telling from our colleagues, including those from the LGBT+ community. Our over-arching statement about diversity and inclusion is: 'At L&G, we stand for inclusion. Get this right, and our culture will speak to a future where we’re known for being fair, transparent, customer-led, and economically and socially useful. A workplace where differences breed originality, and you can be at your best no matter who you are'. The language on our careers site is deliberately focused on how we aim to empower people to be at their best no matter who they are which is all encompassing. This is also reflected in the imagery we use, for example in our 'Diversity and Inclusion at Legal & General' video, which includes video footage of members of our LGBT+ community. Diversity and Inclusion at L&G video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=djTs2V4JUFs L&G Life webpage on the our careers site: https://www.legalandgeneral.com/careers/legal-and-general-life Example LGBT+ employee testimonials: https://www.linkedin.com/posts/legal-%26-general_pridemonth-pride-lgbt-activity-7211279397897601024-fC4r https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/pride-month-like-other-andrzej-pioch-cfa/ https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/active-allyship-using-my-privilege-bring-people-together-ahuja/ Statement from our CEO: https://www.linkedin.com/posts/ant%C3%B3nio-sim%C3%B5es_onwardsandupwards-pridemonth-legalandgeneral-activity-7212397274390278144-dpKm?utm_source=li_share&utm_content=feedcontent&utm_medium=g_dt_web&utm_campaign=copy
column57: How does your organisation seek to position itself as an LGBTQ+ inclusive employer?
column58: L&G careers site: employee testimonials and storytelling from our colleagues including from the LGBT+ community (see detail provided in response to Q1). LGBT+ Allies Network: set up by L&G in 2018 as a group-wide network for colleagues who identify as LGBT+, plus their allies. Partnership with LGBT Great. Partnership with Just Like Us: L&G partnership with Just Like Us (JLU) to help eliminate homophobic, bi-phobic and transphobic bullying in school by empowering young people to champion LGBT+ equality and challenge prejudice. Pride: L&G active involvement in Pride across London/Hove/Chicago/Birmingham/Cardiff. In 2024 L&G was also an event sponsor at Cardiff pride and ran an event stall focused on attraction and recruitment. Support for LGBT+ community: Colleagues are able to show our support for diverse communities by downloading our Pride logo, email signature and social media banners. The L&GBT+ Allies Network also gives out merch with our pride logo during pride month, including water bottles, tote bags, t-shirts, pin badges, lanyards and other items that colleagues can wear and carry to show support.

column69: Please describe and attach examples of the content covered by this training.
column70: The LGBT allyship training offers practical advice and strategies on how employees can actively support their LGBT+ colleagues and create a welcoming environment for all. The training also delves into the meaning and history of Pride, exploring its origins, significance, and evolution over the years. This section provides context on why Pride is celebrated and its ongoing importance in promoting equality and visibility for the LGBT+ community. Additionally, the training keeps employees informed about current news and events related to Pride, ensuring everyone is aware of important developments and initiatives. Finally, it introduces our company's LGBT network, outlining the resources, groups, and support systems available to employees. This network serves as a valuable tool for fostering connection and creating a sense of community within the workplace. In addition to the resources attached we have hosted and made available to L&G employees in-person and virtual events, hosted with partners such as LGBT Great and Interinvest. In June we hosted the Allyship Unmasked event, this inspiring event brought a captivating journey into the heart of allyship, where industry heroes shared their transformative stories of support and solidarity. The event was a collaborative effort with LGBT Great, and we welcomed peers from various financial services companies to convene at our Coleman Street premises for an engaging panel discussion. In August we celebrated South Asian Heritage Month, and held an event with the theme 'Free to Be Me' in collaboration with Interinvest. We were delighted to welcome Laks Mann MBE from the South Asian Heritage Month team. He illustrated how FreeToBeMe enables us to celebrate our backgrounds and the dynamic nature of identity in different contexts and intersectionality. In September we hosted the InterInvest Bi+ Awareness Week panel, in partnership with Just Like Us! The panel was an insightful conversation with Ambassadors from Just Like Us, who will shed light on how the next generation increasingly views sexuality as fluid and on the expectations around bi+** inclusion in the workplace and LGBTQ+ spaces.
column73: If yes, please attach a copy of the policy and provide examples of how you hold your suppliers to account on LGBT+ DE&I.
column74: We hold ourselves and our employees to high standards when it comes to role modelling responsible behaviour as it’s important to us that all our stakeholders can expect us to behave fairly and to do the right thing. We have a number of a Group-wide policies that highlight our commitment to ethical and responsible behaviour, which you can find below. Legal & General are acutely aware of how our business impacts on society and the environment. We are proud of being a company that does business responsibly and ethically. We strive to work with like-minded businesses and use our supplier governance processes to promote socially responsible behaviour across the supply chain. Legal & General require our suppliers to comply with our Supplier Code of Conduct at all times and be able to demonstrate compliance. The purpose of our Supplier Code of Conduct is to clarify and safeguard the relationships between us and our suppliers, to establish standards that ensure our suppliers operate ethically, are environmentally responsible and that workers are treated with respect and dignity. Our suppliers must have processes in place to maintain these standards and be able to provide evidence if required. These processes are scrutinised closely both as part of the procurement process but also as part of the ongoing commercial arrangement. This code of conduct is reviewed and recertified on an annual basis to ensure that are supplier remains compliant with the policy. For key suppliers, Legal & General hold formal quarterly and annual strategic reviews where performance, opportunities and strategic alignment are reviewed. We have published an organisation-wide agenda to make discussions on topics, such as sustainability and corporate social responsibility, a standard practice of working with suppliers. This includes areas such as employee welfare, the living wage as well as diversity and inclusion within the supplier’s business. We encourage collaboration between organisations on issues such as LGBTQ+ and have held joint meetings between employee resource groups to drive progress on shared objectives. Since 2021 we have been a member of the Social Enterprise UK. which is the biggest network of social enterprises in the UK. This membership allows for us to search and engage with suppliers for various products and services within the Social Enterprise UK community.

column89: If yes, please describe the process.
column90: Within Legal & General there are a number of policies to foster an inclusive environment and the HR department in particular have liaised with the L&GBT+Allies Network to ensure that the policies reflect considerations within the LGBT+ community and this is illustrated in the following: • The Diversity and Inclusion policy – to ensure that no job applicant, fellow employee or worker, customer or supplier is discriminated against on the grounds of: Age, Religion or belief, Creed, Colour, Disability, Gender or gender identity, Gender reassignment, Marital status or civil partnership status, Nationality, National origin, Parental carer status, Pregnancy, childbirth, maternity or paternity, Race or ethnic origin, Sexual orientation, Transgender, Union membership, Reduced hours working • The Dignity at Work policy – this states that L&G care about the people we work with and for, which is why we’re committed to creating a work environment free from harassment and bullying where everyone is treated with dignity and respect regardless of their sexual orientation, gender identity and gender expression • The Adoption, Maternity, Paternity and Shared parental leave policies all state that benefits apply regardless of gender • Trans and Non-binary policy which ensures that L&G provide support to any employee who is intending to change their name and gender in the workplace and to make sure that the systems are updated to reflect this. It also shows a clear commitment to supporting all trans people, including those with non-binary identities with information on language and terminology and guidance on facilities and dress code • Healthcare Insurance – The current L&G policy is open to all employees and their partners regardless of their gender and gender identity, and dependents. The policy provides a maximum of £10,000 for trans individuals to enable pre-operative support in the form of Cognitive Behaviour Therapy and Psychotherapy. All our policies were reviewed and signed off by our ERGs, the union and Stonewall. The trans and non binary policies were signed off by Stonewall and the Global Butterflies. We also ensure that all our comms (internal and external) are inclusive
column93: If yes, please list the organisations.
column94: The Summers Work Experience programme, which we have been able to continue since 2019, provides young people from schools, colleges and several social enterprises (including Investment20/20) who have no work experience opportunities with two weekly programmes. The aim is to equip these individuals with invaluable insight into aspects of the corporate world, such as the diversity of roles and entry formats available to them, as well as assisting them in selecting a career path, building their confidence, learning new skills and facilitating professional networking opportunities. We also continue to host two ‘Meet the Stemettes’ events - a panel of female employees answered questions from an audience of 9 to 13 year olds and gave advice on work experience, GCSE options and also questions about their jobs. Similarly, we regularly host student insight days with industry professionals from a varied range of backgrounds and business areas presented and offered top career tips to students. LGIM is supporting the #10000Blackinterns initiative aimed at encouraging young black talented individuals to consider a career in asset management. LGIM is working hard alongside our peers to make our industry more accessible and to ensure everyone has the same opportunity to succeed. We have also partnered with Girlguiding, the UK’s largest charity for girls and young women, to support and sponsor their new Saver badge. This is an initiative aimed at encouraging guides to develop their understanding of money, making finances accessible and easy to understand. This is particularly important as 53% of women between 17 and 21 say that having to pay university fees is one of their biggest fears of the future. Finally, we have been involved in several high profile initiatives through Diversity Project, Investment 2020, Fast Futures, 30% Club, LGBT Great, #talkaboutblack including the #IAM campaign, the Vision Foundation, Moving Ahead and Investing in Ethnicity, Employers Network for Equality & Inclusion (ENEI), Business in the Community / BITC Cymru, Women in Finance Charter, Race at Work Charter, Out in Finance (an LGBTQ+ industry initiative in Chicago) to raise awareness of the importance of LGBT+ inclusion in the workplace.

column110: Senior leaders actively support LGBT+ activities and encourage teams/team managers to think about advocacy and working as an ally. We partner with LGBT Great to showcase our role models and historically a number of Senior Leaders at exco level globally have made the LGBT Great Top 50 and Top 100 Allies list. column114: Employees are encouraged to volunteer (and time is made available) for LGBT+ activities. Networks are used to reach out to new joiners who may be interested in taking a more active role and/or understanding what networks are available. • External network activity: L&G has active membership with various LGBT+ specialist organisations to promote LGBT+ inclusion and allyship, wherein we formally call out employees to become visible role models. • Internal network activity to encourage visible role models: o Our internal network is open to all; with the name (L&GBT+Allies) and the objectives promoting inclusion and allyship o The network has a formal call to action that goes out regularly to recruit visible role models. We send out regular communications advising all employees of events such as Pride, virtual and in person social networking, educational events; where we encourage our allies to bring along new allies to increase visibility and awareness. o We use all forms of communications available to promote events – Viva Engage, intranet page, emails and our dedicated Teams Channel with additional channels for location. This helps to promote the network to all L&G offices and employees across different divisions and levels, which has helped to bring in new visible role models. o The network is run by visible volunteers across the organisation and actively supported by HR, Brand and Workspaces teams. o Over the last year we have published blogs (internally & externally via our social media channels) written by LGBT+ members and allies - members & execs - to promote importance of being visible role model. o L&G has official LGBT+ logo or Rainbow company logo which employees can add to their signature to show that they are visible role models and show support. L&G also has LGBT+ lanyard that employees can wear at work. We continue to have our Gender Pronouns on signatures across the group and a LGBT Screen Saver for Pride featuring our employees.

column49: What campaigns, strategies or approaches has your organisation undertaken to improve comfort around disclosing self-ID DE&I data?
column50: We have an intranet page fully explaining how colleagues sharing their data with us. Five reasons to share your diversity data 1 It will make a significant positive difference To understand and best support our diverse population, we need accurate data. Without it, how can we be sure we're making the right decisions and focusing on the areas that will make the biggest difference? 2 It’s secure Much like your bank details and salary, your personal information is completely secure. In fact, it’s only visible to you and a handful of colleagues with super-user access. Your data is stored and managed following strict GDPR guidelines and will never be used for any other purpose. 3 It’s not just about you We need to think big picture. The data you choose to share will give us a clearer view of the many facets of who we all are and will be used to inform decisions at a wider level. The more data we have, the clearer the view. Plus, accurate data allows us track, evidence and celebrate whenever we make meaningful positive changes. 4 It’s easy It’s just a case of answering a few questions. It only takes a minute and you can update your responses at any time. Just log in to your local HR portal and select the Diversity Form. 5 It’s optional, but… We all have a role to play in improving inclusion and diversity across the Group, so a response from every colleague would be ideal. You can respond ‘prefer not to answer’ to any of the questions, which is a perfectly valid response. Even if you feel you're fully represented, adding your data will help because more responses mean more accurate stats. Check out the Data Collection FAQs for more information about how your data is stored and used in line with GDPR guidelines.
column53: How does your organisation target and attract LGBTQ+ talent?
column54: All adverts are run through a gender decoder before being advertised to remove bias where possible (https://www.totaljobs.com/insidejob/gender-bias-decoder/insights/). This is a mandatory step within our recruitment process. • We have an Equal Opportunities statement within our adverts: Open, honest and fair. That’s how we treat our people. We’ve worked hard and continue to work hard to create a positive, inclusive atmosphere, based on respect for people’s differences. We’re committed to equality of opportunity and treatment for all those who work for us. In line with our values, we treat everyone fairly and with respect, irrespective of gender, marital status, sexual orientation, race, colour, nationality, ethnic origin, culture, religion or belief, age, disability or any other reason that cannot be reasonably justified. Through our Equality and Diversity Policy, plus all our other People Policies, we make sure that everyone’s valued and treated equally and fairly, with dignity and respect. Additionally our TA team • hold regular focus groups with our affinity groups (gender balance, social mobility, LGBT+, disability) so we can understand how and what people look for when searching for a new role • Advertising on our socials that we are proud of our colleagues being able to be themselves in the workplace • Constantly reviewing our job boards, and looking at partnerships with specialist jobs • Preferred Supplier List reviews include understanding how our suppliers support equal opportunities within their practice/policies/procedures

column5: For each of the selected answers in Q1, please describe what responsibilities they have for LGBTQ+ DE&I in your organisation.
column6: We have the following governance structure to support LGBT+ inclusion at our organization. The DEI Committee is comprised of representatives from the Executive Committee, Senior Management and Human Resources. The Committee sets the firm overall DEI strategy, monitors progress and allocates budgetary resources. We also have a dedicated regional council. The council is responsible for implementing our strategy at the regional level. Our ERGs lead on championing grass-roots efforts led by employees and support our overall diversity, equity and inclusion goals. DEI Regional Council The Regional Councils are comprised of regional employees who identify aspects of diversity and inclusion relevant and important in their region. They collaborate with the DEI Committee and Employee Resource Groups to implement strategy at a local level. We have three regional councils EMEA, Asia Pacific and North America that support our DEI Strategy. Employee Resource Groups The Employee Resource Groups (ERG) are grassroots, employee-led effort that offer colleagues with common interests an opportunity to meet on a regular basis and discuss how they can make Janus Henderson a more inclusive workplace for all.

column13: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column14: As part of our ongoing commitment to fostering an inclusive workplace, we are pleased to announce several key initiatives designed to recognise and support our Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) efforts across the organization. These initiatives aim to celebrate our achievements, reinforce our culture-building goals, and ensure the continuous development of our employees and leaders in DEI-related activities. 1. DEI Awards Program Launch: This year marks the introduction of our DEI Awards, a significant initiative to acknowledge the exceptional contributions of our Employee Resource Groups (ERGs) and individual members who have played a pivotal role in driving specific campaigns, such as LGBTQ+ History Month. This program enables both our CEO and the organization to honour outstanding efforts in advancing our DEI objectives. 2. Integration of ERG Goals in Year-End Reviews: We are requesting ERG Leaders to incorporate their specific DEI targets into their Performance Reviews (PR). This inclusion will ensure that managers consider the achievements in culture-building and DEI objectives as integral components of the overall employee evaluation process. 3. HR Communications to Managers: To reinforce our DEI commitments, HR will periodically issue reminders to managers. These communications are designed to encourage managers to actively support ERG Leads within their teams by promoting their projects and fostering an environment of active allyship across the broader organization. 4. Executive Sponsor Recognition: To further acknowledge the efforts of our ERG Leads, Executive Sponsors will send personalised emails to line managers. These communications will highlight the importance of recognising ERG Lead contributions and ensuring they receive the necessary support to bring our firm’s values to life. 5. LGBT Great Initiative Participation: We continue to nominate employees for external recognition through the LGBT Great initiative, celebrating LGBT+ role models and allies within our firm. Selected individuals will be spotlighted on our social media channels, and we will sponsor their participation in conferences and training sessions to further their development.
column17: For each of the selected responses in Q7, please describe what proactive actions have been taken in the last 12 months by individuals and the organisation.
column18: We are excited to share several strategic initiatives that underscore our firm’s commitment to diversity, equity, inclusion (DE&I), and leadership development within our Employee Resource Groups (ERGs). These initiatives represent powerful actions taken to not only foster an inclusive workplace but also to empower our ERG leaders and members with the skills and opportunities they need to excel and drive meaningful change. Innovative Mentoring Programs: At the forefront of our efforts is the development of a comprehensive mentoring program, spearheaded by the Executive Sponsor of our Pride ERG. This program, which includes mentoring, reciprocal mentoring, and reverse mentoring elements, is designed to facilitate a rich exchange of ideas, experiences, and insights among employees. Leveraging resources from LGBT Great, this initiative aims to launch in 2025, setting a new benchmark for leadership development and inclusion within our firm. Elevated Internal Training and Coaching: Recognising the pivotal role of continuous learning, we have institutionalised bi-annual refresher training for our ERG Leads. This initiative is tailored to ensure that our leaders remain at the cutting edge of DE&I practices, leadership strategies, and the management of dynamic and effective ERGs. External Training and Leadership Development: To further our commitment to nurturing our leaders, we are placing our ERG Leads on esteemed talent programs designed to enhance their leadership capabilities. This external coaching and training initiative is aimed at equipping our leaders with the skills necessary to inspire, guide, and make an impactful difference both within and outside our organization. Access to LGBTQ+ Focused Conferences and Events: We are providing our ERGs with unparalleled access to leading LGBTQ+ focused conferences and events, such as D&I Leaders. This access is crucial for keeping our ERG skill sets supported, fostering innovation, and ensuring our initiatives reflect the latest in DE&I thought leadership. Executive Sponsorship and Network Opportunities: Our Pride ERG’s Executive Sponsor is actively connecting our ERGs with a broader network of ERG sponsors and allies. This initiative is designed to enhance visibility, foster collaborations, and unlock new opportunities for our ERG members to engage, learn, and grow. These initiatives represent our firm's proactive and strategic approach to DE&I and leadership development. By investing in our people, fostering an inclusive culture, and creating pathways for professional growth, we are not only enhancing the employee experience but also driving forward our mission to be a leader in DE&I.
column22: Where possible, we feature colleagues to deliver events and talks – for example, this year our Executive Sponsors for Pride and the Black Professional network role modelled collaboration and allyship by opening our private cinema viewing of the Rustin to celebrate LGBTQ+ History Month UK and Black History Month US in February. We appreciate that discussion spaces have the most impact when delivered by colleagues with the lived experience, and encourage these conversations through our Pride ERG's 'As me anything' event, which over 50+ attendees, and we ensured to record the session so our colleagues globally could watch this in their own time. We featured our PRIDE Executive Sponsor, who is an ally of LGBT+ to communicate a firm-wide email campaign to encourage colleagues to get involved in activities and find resources to enrich their learning on LGBT+ topics. This post was sent to our 2000+ colleagues to ensure the widest reach. We ensure individual champions, who are not part of the ERG leadership team and go above and beyond are recognised in our new feature of JHI DEI Awards at the Town Hall. For example, this year, we featured Ben Walker who spearheaded our London viewing of Rustin. We also have an open question for DEI Ally of the Year to capture any additional efforts taking place across the firm. Our ERG’s also select roles model each year to showcase based on the actions they have taken to support LGBT+ Inclusion. We also create summary posts to show the accumulative power of the work we are doing to support our LGBTQ+ employees and how we are benchmarked objectively eg. Human Rights Index, LGBT Great Gold Accreditation. The aim of sharing these wins is also highlight our self-ID campaign to encourage more role models and allies to self-disclosure the demographic data.

column26: Our DEI strategy is encompassing of our LGBTQ+ strategy and therefore for all employees. Based on the objectives, the team will provide policy and benefit recommendations, identify trends in exit data and raising awareness regarding opportunity gaps to the Diversity Committee, identify new recruiting sources and host employee events that educate and provide an opportunity for employees to network. In the past, we have modified our dress code and leave policies to be more inclusive. In 2022, based on recommendations from our PRIDE ERG, we reviewed our existing benefits and recommended a reimbursement allowance benefit for up to $50,000 – for fertility, surrogacy, adoption, and gender affirmation. This enhance was implemented into our plan in 2023. We have provided additional trans inclusion training and implemented a trans inclusion guideline. We have posted our roles on LGBT+ job boards and sponsored LGBT+ community events.

column6: Executive Committee - ultimately responsible for company culture, strategic oversight, budget distribution and open and vocal support of LGBTQ+ and DE﹠I initiatives in the company. Responsible for the provision of company benefits to ensure employees have equality of access. Employee Resource Groups (Networks at Beazley) - responsible for engaging employees, celebrating key dates in the diversity calendar, sharing stories, encouraging education and providing feedback on company initiatives, policies or procedures that may affect our LGBTQ+ population

column33: For each of the selected options in Q6, please list the policy and provide supporting commentary. Please attach a copy of the policies.
column34: Discrimination based on sexual orientation policy - diversity policy attached Discrimination based on gender identity and expression policy - diversity policy attached Transitioning at work (or equivalent) policy - policy screenshot attached. Wording: In line with our Inclusion & Diversity Policy, Beazley commits to recruit, retain and develop people with diverse backgrounds and experiences to thrive at all levels of our business, in a truly inclusive environment that operates zero tolerance to discrimination or harassment and fully supports and celebrates differences. This guide is for all managers and colleagues and is designed to provide support and information to assist anyone going through the transitioning process and once they have transitioned. ‘Trans’ is an overarching term to describe people whose gender is not the same as, or does not align comfortably with the sex they were assigned at birth. Transitioning involves the various steps a trans person may take to live in the gender with which they identify. Each person’s experience will be different. For some this involves medical intervention but not all trans people will have this. Transitioning may also involve changing pronouns, telling friends, family or colleagues, dressing differently or changing official documents and we understand that the levels of support an individual may require will vary. If an individual is considering transition, there are a number of things we can do at Beazley to support them. We encourage the individual to speak with their line manager and/or relevant C&P Business Partner in the first instance. Confidentiality Trans and non-binary colleagues will take the lead as to whether, when and how they wish to discuss their status. We understand some people may want to keep their gender identity private where others may wish to discuss either in confidence or more openly. We will respect the rights of the individual and great care will be taken not to do anything or share any information that breaches this confidentiality. Any information gathered by Beazley is held securely and only accessed by authorised colleagues with a legitimate need for the information. Absences from work We appreciate individuals may need to be away from work for medical appointments or surgical procedures as well as recovery time. The individual may also wish to work remotely for a period of time while undergoing any procedures. The individual should discuss any planned absences in advance with their line manager and/or relevant C&P Business Partner so the appropriate leave policies can be applied or adjustments made. We encourage the line manager and individual to remain in contact during any absences to agree any return to work plans or discuss any further adjustments that may be required. Communication The individual will confirm their details, the date effective and by what pronouns they wish to be addressed in the business moving forwards by discussing with their line manager and/or relevant C&P Business Partner. The C&P team will ensure records, directories, email accounts and so on are updated accordingly. The individual and their line manager should discuss how the individual wishes to communicate to others in the team or wider business of their name or pronoun change and agree how this should be done. Should the team or manager require more support, the C&P Business Partner or Inclusion Partner will be able to advise. It will be made clear that any transphobic or discriminatory comments will not be tolerated. Examples of this could be not respecting someone’s pronouns continued use of a trans person’s “deadname” (birth name or name they used prior to transitioning), being subjected to derogatory remarks about their gender identity, being “outed” or excluded as a result of their gender identity. Beazley operates a zero-tolerance policy towards any form of discrimination and any examples of transphobic bullying or harassment will be investigated fully. Facilities & Dress Code All colleagues are entitled to use the toilet or changing facilities appropriate to the gender in which they align with, regardless of whether they are currently undergoing or have undergone any gender reassignment. A number of Beazley offices have gender-neutral facilities which are available to use for all colleagues to use too. Beazley have a ‘dress for the day’ gender-neutral policy so individuals are empowered to use their own judgement on what to wear given their working day. If you have any questions about this document, the support available or would like to discuss further, either as someone considering or undergoing their transition or supporting another individual, please contact your C&P Business Partner Inclusive parental leave policy (i.e. shared maternity & parental leave) - policy screenshot attached. Inclusivity is at the heart of what we do, that’s why no matter how individuals come to parenthood, if they are a permanent employee they are entitled to 26 weeks fully paid leave as a day one right. Adoption leave policy - policy screenshot attached

column13: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column14: Employees are rewarded for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DEI in similar ways to other roles and projects they carry out in the firm – these are a combination of tangible and intangible rewards. Tangible rewards in the form of pay and bonuses are reviewed on an annual basis taking into account feedback from colleagues on each individual’s activities and performance over the year. Feedback on DEI work forms part of this process and can therefore influence reward. Intangible reward and recognition is provided through communications internally referring to named individuals who are leading on DEI projects, naming and recognition of Network members’ roles on internal SharePoint pages, and general visibility and recognition of each person’s contribution.

column17: For each of the selected responses in Q7, please describe what proactive actions have been taken in the last 12 months by individuals and the organisation.
column18: Internal/ external training: The firm provides training sessions, open to all employees, as part of the LGBT+ committee Pride month on an annual basis. This began in 2023 with a webinar from Global Butterflies followed by the LGBT Great Language Matters session in June 2024. These training sessions were facilitated by BW staff from the Pride Network and the sessions were led and presented by external trainers. The sessions have been recorded and made available and promoted to all staff, including leaders in the organisation, to view, although they were not specifically targeted at leadership. A separate training session was delivered by Kin&Co, external DEI consultants, to BW’s Management board in 2024, as part of the initial stage of a project led by Kin&Co to review and re-design BW’s overall strategy. Whilst this training was not specifically on LGBTQ+ issues, the LGBTQ+ perspective was covered as part of the DEI training. This project to review the DEI Strategy was pro-actively taken to Management Board by the DEI Steering Committee, led by Simon Rusling. Access to LGBTQ+ focussed conferences and events: External events are promoted and made available for all people in BW to attend, including leadership, although these have not been specifically targeted at the firm’s leadership. These events include O:pen and other industry LGBTQ+ focussed events which are mainly promoted via the Pride Network and the Network’s Viva Engage internal social platform. The firm’s management board also has updates and interaction with those involved in LGBTQ+ DEI work in other ways: DEI Steering Committee prepare a report for management board on a quarterly basis to update management board on the progress of DEI work. Andrew Vaughan, our Senior Partner, meets with our DEI Network leads (including the LGBTQ+ Network lead) every 6 months to connect and discuss ongoing DEI initiatives.
column19: Evidence of several initiatives in place to support leadership in understanding LGBTQ+ issues.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dMon, 14 Oct 2024 15:41:21 GMT|
column22: We highlight role models and allies from our Pride Network internally via posts on our Viva Engage workplace social platform (which are viewed by a relatively small proportion of employees who have subscribed to these updates) and through occasional firmwide email communications, say every six months, such as part of Pride month communications. We also highlight these role models and allies in posts externally on social media during Pride month or on our external website (on our DE&I website pages).
column23: Evidence of a multi-channel approach to spotlighting supportive role models and allies both internally and externally.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dMon, 14 Oct 2024 15:41:21 GMT|

column49: What campaigns, strategies or approaches has your organisation undertaken to improve comfort around disclosing self-ID DE&I data?
column50: Aligned HR and Network campaign launched in July 2024 to drive completion. Phase 1 activities included: - research into best practice and gained insight from other organisations - test group used to understand where and what barriers exist, to help inform campaign contents - each DEI network posts video to their community sharing the importance of data and how it can be used (variety of topics) - each Executive Sponsor of the DEI networks posts to their community sharing why it’s important to them to share their data - Targeted communications to Partners, Principals, “Vice Principals”, and Department Leaders to target low completion areas - Creation of resources to for audience to read more about key topics such as data security, how to input data, how it will be used - Visual displays in each office to encourage completion - Mentioned in key firmwide communications such as the Senior Partner’s Quarterly Briefings

column13: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column14: We run an employee recognition scheme, for which employees can be nominated for in light of their contributions in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I and Inclusion as a whole. During performance appraisals, all employees are reviewed on both business excellence and behaviour rating. For the purposes of behaviour rating, all managers have a cascaded goal of living up to our six manager expectations – one of which is being an enabler of inclusion and diversity. Evidence of their contribution may include, but not limited to, involvement in LGBT+ inclusion activity for which is considered as part of performance rating reviews.

column73: If yes, please attach a copy of the policy and provide examples of how you hold your suppliers to account on LGBT+ DE&I.
column74: Yes, our organisation has a procurement policy to encourage LGBTQ+ DE&I with its suppliers. The Schroders procurement policy does not specifically reference LGBTQ+ DE&I, however we expect Schroders suppliers to follow the Supplier Code of Conduct which has a section about inclusion Inclusion, diversity and fair wages Schroders strives to create an inclusive culture that celebrates diversity. Our vision is for our people to reflect the diversity of the communities we live and work in. And for everyone to feel they truly belong at Schroders. Information about our approach can be found here. We believe in fair pay for performance, providing a good work environment that prioritises wellbeing, and providing personal growth opportunities. This helps us attract and retain exceptional employees. We are accredited living wage employers in both the United Kingdom (UK) and the United States of America (USA) and pay at least 10% above the minimum wage in all our locations globally. We expect our suppliers and their subcontractors to: - Abide by all relevant equality legislation in the countries in which they operate. - Be transparent, fair and consistent through any employment or hiring practices, ensuring there is no discrimination on the basis of age, sex or sexual orientation, gender identity, disability, origin, race, colour, religion or belief. - Embrace diversity, fairness and inclusion in their workforce/workplace, free from discrimination. - Comply with all applicable wage and working regulations and encourage suppliers to go beyond compliance with local minimum wages and, where applicable, pay a living wage to all direct employees and contractors. We also encourage our suppliers to support the adoption of the local living wage throughout its supply chain. - We will not tolerate harassment or discrimination in our working environment including that of our suppliers. When working at and for Schroders, if suppliers experience or witness any discriminatory actions or comments, we encourage these to be reported using the whistleblowing process detailed in section 6 below.

column117: If yes, please describe how this was achieved and attach a copy of your dress code.
column118: Our dress code centres around dressing appropriately for your day. This means formal business attire if meeting clients or representing the company externally, business casual if in the office but not interacting with clients, and more casual again if you are working from home and not interacting with clients. Examples given of business casual are: – Smart casual trousers, including jeans and chinos – Smart casual skirts and dresses – Smart casual shirts with a collar including polo shirts – Smart casual footwear, including clean, well presented trainers However the above are not gendered- and any option would be considered appropriate for anyone- regardless of biological sex or gender identity. The list of inappropriate clothing includes ripped jeans, flip flops, leggings, and anything with a noticeable logo or offensive image. Excluding these items from the list of accepted clothing does not discriminate against or disproportionately impact those from the LGBTQ+ community.

column5: For each of the selected answers in Q1, please describe what responsibilities they have for LGBTQ+ DE&I in your organisation.
column6: Executive Committee: Our LGBTQ ERG group has an executive committee member who is assigned to the group as their executive sponsor. He proactively joins the monthly ERG meetings and supports initiatives related to LGBTQ that the group and our firm organises. The executive sponsor has joined almost all of the meetings in the past 24-months. Our firm participates in the Tokyo Rainbow Pride Parade each year in which several of our executive committee members join. They also actively join our Pride Month activities. Non-Executive Management: Members of Non-Executive Management head departments such as Corporate Sustainability. They participate in various DE&I initiatives including those related to LGBTQ, as well as leading and participating in the LGBTQ Group. Human Resources: We have two employees from HR who participate in our LGBTQ ERG. One of them is a lead for the group. Although same-sex marriage is not legalized in Japan, the HR Dept has worked to make some employee benefits for spouses available to partners of LGBTQ employees. ERG: We have a very active LGBTQ+ ERG in Japan. Their activities are mentioned in more detail throughout this assessment. The group recently worked to launch a firm-wide ally network in March 2024, which has garnered the participation of more than 90 employees globally. Other employees: The ERG activities are supported by the Global Sustainability team which consists of the Corporate Sustainability Department based in Tokyo-HQ, as well as the rest of the Global Sustainability team in Singapore who collaborate to support efforts in the international offices. The Global Sustainability team helps with budgeting, logistical activities such as planning and operating of events, and communication in various channels.

column18: We have ongoing partnership with organizations like LGBT Great and Massachusetts LGBT Chamber of Commerce that provide various events that attendees can attend, including training. As a founding sponsor of the Massachusetts LGBT Chamber of Commerce, BBH also participates in roundtable discussions to share best practices with other sponsor organizations and participates in routine LGBT-focused job fairs. Internally we include LGBTQ+ topics in our in-house training options and resources on websites. Our BANCS (ERGs) hold events that include a training component and employee engagement .
column22: LGBTQ+ Role models and Allies are highlighted through employee stories, quotes etc. on internal /external websites, articles on social media, hosting ERG events etc. For example, For PRIDE month, The Pride Network hosted a global panel discussion on Inspiring Allies into Action and hearing first-hand accounts from BBHers of how they personally put their Allyship into Action or from individuals that have been positively impacted by these actions. We also have an ongoing feature “How I Lead Series” which features LGBTQ+ allies.
column25: For each of the selected options in Q3, please describe how your LGBTQ+ DE&I strategy addresses each option.
column26: Recruitment & selection We participate in job fairs that are specifically targeted towards LGBT community. Our promotional materials and website (BBH.com) include information about PRIDE network and LGBTQ+ initiatives. BBH supports equal employment opportunity, which is listed on the website and has policies in place again discrimination by any protected categories including sexual harassment, gender identity, gender expression, etc. We are connected with partners such as LGBT great, Massachusetts LGBT Chamber of Commerce, Pride in Our Workplace Boston, Open Finance in New York City and Equality Signs Federation (Federacja Znaki Rownosci) in Krakow, Poland to continue to support LGBTQ+ recruitment. Talent retention – In addition to Benefits, L&D etc. we engage with our PRIDE Network to connect with our colleagues at grassroot levels through various initiatives and events that bring people together. For example: Celebrating PRIDE month with events such as, Authentic Allyship: Inspiring Stories from LGBTQ+ Allies; Luxembourg Pride 2024 Equality March; Raising the flag; Pride & Parenting – The Power of Books, etc. Learning & development – In addition to in-house training, we partner with organizations to bring training and awareness about LGBTQ+ . For example: Make the Most of Your Workplace Relationships -LGBT Great’s Mentoring Program, Intentions, Impact & Assumptions: How to Be a Great Ally to Your LGBTQ+ Colleagues with Massachusetts LGBT Chamber of Commerce etc. Additionally, annual compliance trainings include LGBTQ+ Topics and scenarios. Pay, reward & benefits – We review and update our benefits and information on an ongoing basis to be inclusive for LGBTQ+ Community. For example, launch of LGBTQ+ employee benefit guide DEI Data Capture/Analysis /KPI - We have systems like Workday that help us to capture self ID data. This enables us to look at our representation and employee engagement information through various DEI lens, including LGBTQ+. Communications- We work closely with our PRIDE Network, Marketing and other stakeholders to ensure LGBTQ+ communications are integrated into the broader DEI Comms Strategy (Internally and Externally) For example, marketing related to recruitment on external websites, PRIDE engagement articles on social media and internal website.
column27: Evidence of a robust and comprehensive DE&I strategy with clearly defined LGBTQ+ elements addressed throughout.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dMon, 21 Oct 2024 14:50:17 GMT|
column29: If yes, please provide details of the process and which stakeholder is accountable for it? Please ensure that you have the permission of the person referenced to use their name.
column30: LGBTQ+ s part of our DE&I strategy, which is designed and implemented with input from multiple stakeholders within the organization and executed with support of the DE&I Ecosystem – including but not limited to our Employee Resource Groups (BANCS), Executive Support (Senior leaders), Human resources, and other colleagues. All leaders have performance objectives that encompasses DE&I and is measured holistically within their overall performance rating. Each group is assessed in various ways based on their function/role. At the highest level The Global Inclusion Council (GIC), a group of senior leaders, serves as a body of advice and consent, working with the Office of DEI to set the firm’s DEI agenda and strategy, monitor success, and drive accountability. To ensure firmwide execution of our strategy, BBH Affinity Network Community (BANC) leaders and Culture and Inclusion Councils in each region and line of business advise the GIC on specific local issues and integrate initiatives throughout the firm.
column31: Well-defined review process in place to measure and monitor impact of the LGBTQ+ DE&I strategy.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dMon, 21 Oct 2024 14:50:17 GMT|
column33: For each of the selected options in Q6, please list the policy and provide supporting commentary. Please attach a copy of the policies.
column34: For confidentiality purposes, we cannot share copies of the policy. But a sample of policies is provided below for your reference. Our Equal Employment Opportunity Policy and Prohibition Against Workplace Bullying, Discrimination and Harassment prohibits discrimination against the categories listed above (Sexual orientation, gender identity and expression) Policy samples: 1. Discrimination The Firm will not tolerate discrimination on the basis of a person’s race, color, national origin, age, religion, disability status, gender, sex (including pregnancy), sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, genetic information, marital status, an employee’s or their dependent’s reproductive health decision making, or any other category protected under applicable laws (“Protected Characteristics”). This policy applies to all aspects of employment with the Firm, including recruiting, hiring, placement, training, promotion, transfer, discipline, termination, compensation, and benefits.  2. Child Care Leave - Parental Leave All salaried, full-time and part-time employees who work at least 21 hours per week (excluding hourly employees and interns) are eligible to take paid Child Care Leave following the birth or adoption of a child. The number of weeks of Child Care Leave depends on an employee’s status as either a primary or non-primary caregiver and length of service with the Firm. 3. Gender Transition Support in the Workplace Brown Brothers Harriman is committed to fostering an inclusive culture where every employee can be themselves, take pride in their unique background and be respected and valued for their contributions. By creating a work environment based on respect, trust, and collaboration, our employees can bring their whole selves to work and deliver their best. The following guide provides information about the ways in which BBH is committed to supporting our transgender employees. The content is intended to help foster internal dialogue and an understanding of issues for transgender and gender non-conforming employees, their colleagues, managers, human resource professionals, and others who may be involved in a workplace gender transition. 4. Dress Code Policy We're committed to acting in a way that preserves our reputation for teamwork, integrity, and excellence within the financial services industry, our communities, and amongst our colleagues. Our dress code policy aims to celebrate the rich diversity within our community while providing guidance which enables us all to use our best judgement when making office wardrobe choices that promote a neat, clean and professional appearance within our inclusive environment
column35: Evidence of robust and comprehensive policies which are both LGBTQ+ inclusive and explicit. Furthermore the use of inclusive and up-to-date language demonstrates a high level of LGBTQ+ maturity in this area.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dMon, 21 Oct 2024 14:50:17 GMT|

column61: If yes, please name the policy and/or actions that your organisation is taking to reduce bias in the recruitment process and support for line managers.
column62: Manager Training: To help mitigate bias throughout the process, hiring managers with open requisitions complete unconscious bias interview training and evaluate candidates across a structured interview process that leverages competency-based interview questions and incorporates a diverse panel. Job Descriptions: We take great care to create gender-neutral job descriptions that properly scope roles — focusing beyond any narrow, specialized requirements to also consider broader capabilities, transferable skillsets, and long-term leadership skills that are beneficial for the team Diverse Candidate Pools: We seek out a diverse slate of candidates for our positions and identify our applicants from a variety of sources. Through partnerships with our BANCs, schools, external partners, and online communities, we work to ensure we have the broadest reach to talent available in the marketplace Competency-Based Interview Process: During our interviews, we leverage competency-based questions that focus on assessing a candidate’s ability or experience through actual events. By focusing on job relevant behaviors, a competency-based approach helps us ensure greater objectivity, accuracy, and consistency when interviewing multiple candidates for a position. Diverse Panel of Interviewers: To further mitigate unconscious bias, we strive for job candidates to meet with a diverse panel of interviewers.
column63: Evidence of a wide range of initiatives in place to prevent bias in the recruitment process.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dMon, 21 Oct 2024 15:26:23 GMT|

column122: For Confidentiality reasons we cannot attach copies of benefits. However, A LGBTQ+ Health Resource Guide was put together to support LGBTQ+ employees. BBH is dedicated to creating a workplace that supports the inclusion of every employee globally. We strongly believe that each employee deserves respect, to feel a sense of belonging and to have their voices heard. Consistent with those guiding principles, we want to support transgender and gender-diverse BB Hers and their ability to live consistently with their gender identity without fear of discrimination and with the full support of the firm based on our culture of mutual respect, acceptance, and allyship.
