column5: For each of the selected answers in Q1, please describe what responsibilities they have for LGBTQ+ DE&I in your organisation.
column6: There are five pillars of our D&I strategy, one of which is LGBT+. The Executive Level is responsible for the deployment of our strategy and for deployment through our Employee Networks. The D&I Team are responsible for delivering on the strategy and plan. The HR team are responsible for policy development and deployment through HR life-cycle processes such as recruitment, development and talent management. Executive sponsorship for the LGBT+ pillar of the D&I Strategy (Louise Shield – Corporate Affairs Director and Executive Committee member). Non-Executive Management. Executive Sponsorship of the M&G Pride Employee Network (Fintan Bannon – Head of Product and Production (Legal)). Employee Resource Group – the M&G Pride Employee network supports the D&I strategy, driving LGBT+ inclusion within the business.
column7: This shows a well balanced and distributed accountability framework with a clear LGBTQI+ lens.-- LGBTGreat/Lauren /dFri, 02 Aug 2024 10:57:14 GMT|
column9: For each of the selected stakeholder groups in Q3, please describe who they are and how they are measured against LGBTQ+ DE&I goals and objectives. Please confirm that you have the permission of the person referenced to use their name.
column10: Board: Progress against the D&I Strategy is reported to the Board on a 6 monthly basis. The Board provides challenge and feedback on progress, holding the Executive Committee to account on progress against the strategy. All colleagues are invited to take part in our employee engagement survey, and a sub-set of the survey forms the Inclusion Index. The overall responsibility and accountability for year-on-year improvement is held at the Board and Exec Committee level. In addition, each Exec Committee member is held accountable for improvement in their respective Inclusion Index score within their area of responsibility. The M&G inclusion index is cascaded from Exec Management to each people manager with a team of more than 10 people to be able to track year on year improvement of colleague inclusion within their respective teams. The inclusion index is analysed across many aspects of diversity including LGBT+ to ensure there is no significant difference in treatment of the feeling of inclusion of colleagues. If a difference is identified, then those individual teams/managers work with HR to put a plan in place focusing on improving inclusion based on the feedback provided by colleagues. Executive Committee: Louise Shield is the Executive Sponsor of the LGBT+ pillar of the D&I Strategy. Progress against the D&I Strategy is reported to the Executive Committee on a 6 monthly basis, and they are collectively responsible for progress against it. The Executive Committee and direct reports have specific objectives set relating to progress against D&I targets. Senior/Non-Exec Management: Fintan Bannon is the Executive Sponsor for the M&G Pride Network. All Senior leaders reporting directly to an Executive Committee member have objectives set relating to progress against the D&I targets. Other Senior Management have responsibility to disseminate and support D&I events and information with their teams. HR Teams have responsibility to ensure all policies are equitable and non-biased, e.g. parental leave policy, which are written to be gender neutral and have seen an increased uptake from LGBT+ parents and families over the preceding years. The HR Team have also actively embedded D&I into their plans (e.g. recruitment, talent management, learning & development) and are responsible for and have performance measured against delivery The Diversity & Inclusion Team have responsibility for delivery against the D&I Strategy and have performance measured against delivery. The Employee Resource Groups continue to partner on intersectionality across all aspects of diversity including LGBT+, an example of which is a recent collaboration with our Pride Network and Mind Matters, our mental health network, exploring eating disorders and how this can impact the LGBT+ Community.
column11: Evidence that well-distributed, articulated and formalised accountabilities that are met with both ambitious targets and the required systems to communicate the impact to wider business.-- LGBTGreat/Lauren /dFri, 02 Aug 2024 10:57:14 GMT|
column13: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column14: We have a clear ambition of what we want our culture to be and how we want working at M&G to feel for everyone every day: - Tell it like it is - Move forward together - Own it now … with care and integrity. We do all of this in a safe, trusting and inclusive environment where colleagues can speak up if something is wrong and feel able to challenge, knowing appropriate action will be taken. The “how” as well as the “what” is an important part of the performance review process, and underpins the culture at M&G. The “how” and the “what” are culminated in a performance appraisal rating, which influences pay and reward decisions. Employee Resource Group Leaders are expected to include their contributions to the M&G Pride network in their performance planning and year end appraisal conversations with their line managers as part of their performance review discussions. In addition, recognition for those employees who go above and beyond to support an inclusive culture are recognised at M&G’s annual Inclusion Awards, which are hosted and presented by the CEO and members of the Exec Committee. The Award categories are: Role Model of the Year; Rising Star; Network Member of the Year; Inclusion Champion; Wellbeing Champion; Business Impact Champion - a "People's Choice" category, where the winner is voted for by colleagues across the whole business. Many of the nominations include colleagues who are being recognised for their work on LGBT+ inclusion and are visible role models in the community. The Awards are celebrated prominently across TAP, our global communication channel. Previous nominees, finalists and winners have included colleagues championing LGBT+ inclusion. Our colleague recognition app, “Say Thanks”, allows colleagues to say thanks to other colleagues for role modelling our behaviours. It provides a platform to share stories, success and recognise colleagues who are bringing our purpose to life. The app uploads the recognition into Workday, our HR system, to help support mid-year and end of year performance conversations.
column15: This demonstrates a comprehensive and integrated approach to recognising and rewarding LGBTQ+ DE&I efforts at M&G which are clearly embedded in the organisation's culture and values and subsequently reflected in formalised performance management.-- LGBTGreat/Lauren /dFri, 02 Aug 2024 10:57:14 GMT|
column17: For each of the selected responses in Q7, please describe what proactive actions have been taken in the last 12 months by individuals and the organisation.
column18: Internal training and, or, coaching Our Pride Network events are promoted to all employees regionally and globally dependent on subject matter and specifically to our Senior Leader group which consists of 160+ senior leaders globally, to encourage attendance by leaders and for them to personally encourage attendance by their teams. In addition, we have extensive celebration and communication of LGBT+ events and occasions such as IDAHOBIT, PRIDE, LGBT History Month, Lesbian Visibility Week, International Pronouns Day and Transgender Awareness Week, highlighting role models and allies globally as well as promoting internal and external events and resources. (See Box.com evidence folder for 11 documents all starting with the title “Internal Comms …”). Mark McLane supports a number of Diversity and Inclusion steering groups and committees which have taken the work into the business units, providing input and coaching to them and ensuring alignment with the D&I Strategy. Access to LGBT+ focussed conferences or events LGBT Great and Interinvest memberships and promotion of events on a variety of internal media, including TAP, our global communications platform and the Yammer platform. We actively share and promote external events that colleagues and managers can attend, for example, during Pride Month 2024, we promoted the LGBT Great Together with Pride event, as well as a “coming soon” for the M&G and LGBT Great collaborative event in Scotland on the 26th October 2024. (See evidence folder “Internal Comms for Pride 2024 includes Exec Sponsorship, L&D events, role modelling and celebration”) An additional example is IDAHOBIT 2024 internal comms, which promoted LBGT great event “Allyship Unmasked” (See evidence folder "Internal comms IDAHOBIT 2024 includes promotion of LGBT Great Allyship event and role modelling”) Mentoring In 2023 we advertised the LGBT Great mentoring scheme to all colleagues. (See evidence folder “Internal comms on LGBT Great mentoring scheme”). The M&G Pride Network and D&I Team attend team meetings and team events on request to provide insight, information and training on topics such as allyship. We look to actively role model inclusive behaviour, for example featuring Louise Shield as an Executive Sponsor during Pride month (LinkedIn post) and during IDAHOBIT, Pride Committee member Nina Bamford talking about the topic of “no-one left behind” (LinkedIn article) – these are also shared on our internal comms platform. External Training We actively promote external training events on LGBT+ topics. (See evidence folder “Yammer page posts on promoting external events and resources” and as a further example “Internal comms IDAHOBIT 2024 includes promotion of LGBT Great Allies event and role modelling”.) We have worked in collaboration with LGBT Great to deliver two events at M&G offices in 2023 – one in Scotland on 26th October and one in London on 6th December and are currently working with LGBT Great for a 2024 event in Scotland in October. Executive Sponsorship The Pride Network have access to an Executive Business Sponsor (ExCo-1) as well as access to Mark McLane, Head of Diversity, Inclusion and well-being to provide input, coaching and guidance.
column22: In addition to the examples attached above, see evidence folder for some internal examples: “Internal comms on Pride 2024 includes promotion of LGBT Great Allies event and role modelling” “Internal comms LGBT History month including resources and support from Exec Sponsor Louise Shield” We regularly promote the use of a tool that adds pronouns into the M&G email signature, to visibly allow colleagues to express their preferred pronoun which is visible to colleagues, clients, customers and suppliers. This includes a "What's this?" link providing background information as to why M&G believes it is important.
column25: For each of the selected options in Q3, please describe how your LGBTQ+ DE&I strategy addresses each option.
column26: Recruitment & Selection All of our job adverts specifically state the following towards the top of the advert: " We have a diverse workforce and an inclusive culture at M&G plc, underpinned by our policies and our employee-led networks who provide networking opportunities, advice and support for the diverse communities our colleagues represent. Regardless of gender, ethnicity, age, sexual orientation, nationality or disability we are looking to attract, promote and retain exceptional people. We also welcome those who take part in military service and those returning from career breaks.” Talent retention Our talent management process takes into consideration all aspects of diversity and has expanded to include reporting all levels of diversity data as part of the broader talent management cycle including hiring, promotion and succession planning where the data is legally available. Our Inclusion Awards recognise and celebrate colleagues that go above and beyond to support an inclusive culture – see LinkedIn post attached in documents below; Learning and Development We provide development opportunities for our Pride Network leads and we participate in cross industry mentoring opportunities, as well as promoting Allies and support. Development opportunities are available such as training on active allyship and attendance at external and partner events. M&G’s Learning and Development App provides easy access to a wide array of learning and development to all colleagues to access on their device at a time that suits them. Our internal L&D App provide all colleagues the opportunity to explore and develop and this includes LGBTQ+ topics (See evidence folder for a small selection of topics available “Internal L&D App LGBTQ+ resources”.) In addition, our Well-being Wednesday Programme provides an opportunity for all colleagues to invest in their well-being every Wednesday, with recordings available in an On-Demand Channel to provide access as and when it suits colleagues. A recent example includes a Well-being Wednesday event run with our partner Nudge (financial well-being) on 26 June 2024, “Pride and Prosperity”; this masterclass has been created specifically for our LGBTQ+ community but is for anyone who wants to improve their understanding of LGBTQ+ finances and unique differentiators, build confidence and expand their knowledge. Our partners EveryWoman, Worklife Central, Black Women in Asset Management, Business Disability Forum, LGBT Great, 100 Women in Finance provide additional development resources including webinars, podcasts, articles, networking opportunities, support groups and more. (For example see evidence folder ”Yammer page posts on promoting external events and resources”.) Sponsorship of external events such as the Career masterclass Stretch Conference and Everywoman’s Global Summit provides additional opportunity. Pay, Reward and Benefits Our Private Medical Insurance includes gender reassignment, with Transitioning at Work supporting manager guidance in place. Our Employee Assistance Programme provides fully confidential support to our colleagues and their immediate families with all aspects of their lives, including a 24/7 online GP, mental health support service, support, advice and more. Our HR policies are written in inclusive language and designed to be market leading, for example, our parental leave policy which provides equal amount of parental leave (6 months) to anyone becoming a parent, regardless of gender and regardless of how they become a parent (e.g. natural birth, surrogacy, adoption etc.). Employee Exit Our Exit questionnaire asks questions on an inclusive culture, and any areas of concern are flagged for further investigation. These questions are currently reporting at a 90% favourable level. Procurement Our Procurement RFP process includes a question and scoring template for D&I aspects, including questions such as "Is your firm a signatory or member of any equality benchmarks, such as the National Equality Standard, Disability Confident Scheme, Law Society Diversity and Inclusion Charter or Stonewall Workplace Equality Index? If not, is your firm committed to becoming a signatory or member of such a benchmark? If so, which benchmark(s) are you working towards and how and when do you plan to achieve the required standard?" and "Provide details of how your organization ensures an inclusive culture, for example, flexible working, parental leave, time off for other events, transitioning at work policy, D&I policy.
column27: Evidence of a mature and developed strategy with a robust set of actions and initiatives that are innovative, ambitious, and impactful with specific LGBTQ+ aspects. The focus on physical and mental well being initiatives as well as data collecting is both impressive and progressive.-- LGBTGreat/Lauren /dFri, 02 Aug 2024 12:14:53 GMT|

column33: For each of the selected options in Q6, please list the policy and provide supporting commentary. Please attach a copy of the policies.
column34: We don’t have a specific non-binary employees at work policy, but non-gendered language is used throughout all of our policies, and we have a pronoun option on our email signature and business cards. In addition to the policies below, we also have a "Resolving Issues" policy, which sets out how colleagues can get issues resolved, either through formal routes or more informal routes. M&G has employed a Colleague Support Advisor whose role is to support colleagues with any difficulties they may face in the workplace. This is an extract from the policy about the Colleague Support Advisor role: "From being a confidential sounding board to having coaching conversations. Talking it through can really help you know what to do next. Reaching out early can often be the difference between a situation starting to improve or continuing to become more difficult. Our Colleague Support Adviser can facilitate conversations and offer mediation which is often a swifter way of addressing concerns and reducing the detrimental impact for all involved.” We continuously look to improve our policies, with recent additions including a “Perimenopause, menopause and other hormone imbalance conditions” policy and the addition of fertility leave to our Inspiring Families policy. Policies: M&G Plc Code of Conduct Inspiring Families Policy (parental and adoption leave, fertility) Transitioning at Work policy Transitioning at work checklist Terminology and definitions Guide Menopause and other hormonal imbalances policy
column35: Clear evidence of robust policies in place to support and empower LGBTQ+ employees and their families with a regular and formalised review process. column61: If yes, please name the policy and/or actions that your organisation is taking to reduce bias in the recruitment process and support for line managers.
column62: Recruitment principles and D&I Guide for Hiring Managers sets out how we go about reducing bias during the recruitment process. M&G’s Recruitment Charter is a set of principles to: • ensure our roles appeal to a broad range of candidates • to help overcome unconscious bias in selection and appointment. In relation to Apprenticeship recruitment: - All colleagues involved with the selection are recommended to complete online “unconscious bias‟ courses and we dedicate part of the assessor workshop to this topic; - Assessors are briefed to challenge each other for bias throughout the process; - Apprentice job descriptions are checked carefully against gender decoder, to remove certain adjectives, or words that can be seen as masculine language or stereotypically gendered words; - CV's are reviewed "blind", with no personal characteristics included; - We use a defined competency based interview script in interviews to ensure all candidates are asked the same questions for consistency and transparency; - We use psychometric tests which are seen as good predictors of performance; - We ensure diverse interview panels; - We challenge „Likability‟ during the final selection stage and focus on evidence; In relation to Graduate recruitment: As well as point above. - Bias training provided for all assessors; - there is no CV screening until final stage; - We undertake a strengths based assessment centre, which includes a mixture of strength based and competency based questions. In relation to experienced hires, all recruiters have completed an unconscious bias training course, and managers are provided with a D&I guide to recruitment
column63: This demonstrates an impressively mature and exhaustive approach to ensuing equity and equality at all stages in the hiring process and clear mechanisms are in place to eliminate unconscious bias.-- LGBTGreat/Lauren /dFri, 02 Aug 2024 16:17:13 GMT|

column118: We have a "How We Work" policy, of which Dress code is one of the areas covered. All of our policies are written in gender neutral language and are reviewed on an annual basis. The appropriate extract is as follows: Dress code It is important to dress appropriately. We ask that you consider the expectations of our customers, colleagues, or partners that you will be interacting with on each working day as well as considering if you are working from an M&G office or your home. This will vary and so can what you wear. If you are in any doubt about what is acceptable, then your manager can guide you.

column122: At M&G we strive to be market leading in our benefits and policies. All of our policies are written to be inclusive of all colleagues. For example, our Inspiring Families policy is designed to be inclusive and all encompassing. An overview of our Inspiring Families policy is below: Being inclusive – an overview to our approach for inspiring families Being inclusive is an important part of our culture, and we want to support all colleagues. Planning a family is different for everyone, and we’re here to support whatever form that takes. If you, your partner or surrogate are undergoing fertility treatment, we provide you paid leave. Families also come in all shapes and sizes and we believe all parents deserve the same opportunity to spend time with their new arrival. We want to keep it simple. However you’re becoming a parent (surrogacy, you/your partner giving birth or adoption), you’ll get an equal amount of paid parental leave to care for your child. And if you’re already a parent, there are other types of family leave available too. Our polices are gender neutral, for example our recent Menopause policy has the following approach: Our approach Perimenopause, menopause and other hormone imbalance conditions, are a natural stage of life that can affect people of any sex, all gender identities, trans and non-binary employees usually between the age of 45 to 50 years but can also happen anytime in someone’s life, for example the menopause or other hormone imbalance conditions may be brought on due to medical reasons We cover gender reassignment within our private medical insurance, and have a transitioning at work policy.

column5: For each of the selected answers in Q1, please describe what responsibilities they have for LGBTQ+ DE&I in your organisation.
column6: Executives: Since EquiLend's inception, our Executives have played a leading role in fostering Diversity & Inclusion efforts at EquiLend. EquiLend's CEO Brian Lamb and EquiLend's CFO Paul Nigrelli have both been featured on LGBT Great's Top 100 Executive Allies list in recognition of their support of LGBT+ inclusion initiatives. Human Resources: EquiLend's Diversity & Inclusion Committee is co-chaired by two members of the Human Resources team at any given time, thus ensuring the Committee's alignment with company D&I strategy and the HR Team's ability to promote the Committee and its activities among EquiLend employees. Diversity & Inclusion & Other Employees: EquiLend's global D&I Committee is comprised of employees across teams, seniority levels, and office locations. Each employee brings their ideas and perspectives to the work of the Committee, and new employees across global locations are invited to join the Committee.
column9: For each of the selected stakeholder groups in Q3, please describe who they are and how they are measured against LGBTQ+ DE&I goals and objectives. Please confirm that you have the permission of the person referenced to use their name.
column10: HR team members who wear the hat of being the Co chairs of the D&I committee have D&I related goals set as part of their Objectives and Key Results for the year. These are reviewed as part of the annual performance review cycle and hence contributes towards their assessment of their performance in a particular year. We also reach out to employees to share feedback regarding the work of the D&I Committee as part of our annual engagement survey in order to ensure that the focus and approach of the D&I activities are in the right direction.
column13: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column14: As part of EquiLend's annual Pride Month celebration, we conducted a series of Pride quizzes throughout the June to encourage employees to learn about LGBT+ history, important dates, identities and more. The employees that came in 1st, 2nd and 3rd place were given the opportunity to select the LGBT+ charity of their choice and EquiLend donated on their behalf. Throughout the year, EquiLend also matches up to $250 USD per employee in donations to any charity of the employees choosing. For Pride Month, the D&I and Charity Committees coordinated a weekend volunteer day in NYC in partnership with the organization God's Love We Deliver, which holds historic ties to the LGBT+ community. All employees who signed up were offered an extra vacation day in recognition of their volunteer service.
column17: For each of the selected responses in Q7, please describe what proactive actions have been taken in the last 12 months by individuals and the organisation.
column18: Mentoring: Several EquiLend employees maintain connections to mentors/mentees they met through LGBT Great's mentoring program. External training and/or coaching: Over the past several years, we've partnered with LGBT Great to offer employees the opportunity to attend trainings tailored to EquiLend's audience on topics such as Allyship and Intersectionality. We've also publicized and encouraged company-wide attendance at LGBT Great's community webinars and events on such topics as LGBT History Month, LGBTQ+ and Black History Month, IDAHOBIT, Covering Culture, and more. Access to LGBTQ+ focused conferences and/or events: EquiLend D&I Committee has always promoted employee access to LGBT Great's community offerings on company-wide channels, as well as publicize information on other LGBT+ focused conferences/events that EquiLend is connected to through our clients or trade associations/regulatory agencies that EquiLend membership to or affiliation with, such as ISLA, FINRA, etc. Executive sponsorship opportunities for LGBTQ+ DE&I/ERG: EquiLend's Executive Sponsor, Paul Nigrelli, has been included several times on LGBT Great's list of Top 100 Executive Allies, and Christopher Gohlke, EquiLend's Head of Marketing & Communications, has also been included on LGBT Great's Top 100 and Top 50 Gamechangers list, plus the Project 1000 Role Models and Allies initiative. As a visible member of the LGBT+ community himself, Christopher was a founding member of EquiLend's Diversity & Inclusion Committee, and was also appointed to the SIFMA Diversity & Inclusion Advisory Council, which aims to advance diversity and inclusion initiatives throughout the U.S. financial services industry.

column25: For each of the selected options in Q3, please describe how your LGBTQ+ DE&I strategy addresses each option.
column26: LGBTQ+ Talent Attraction /Recruitment: At EquiLend we are dedicated to attracting and supporting LGBTQ+ talent through a variety of targeted initiatives. One of those ways is by utilising language decoders to ensure that all our job advertisements are written in inclusive language, making them welcoming to LGBTQ+ candidates. In addition, we actively partner with LGBTQ+ organisations (such as LGBT Great) to connect with a diverse talent pool. Talent retention: EquiLend provides comprehensive diversity and inclusion training to all employees, aiming to create a workplace where everyone feels respected and valued, regardless of their sexual orientation or gender identity. We also formally acknowledge and celebrate our Executive Allies and Gamechangers/Role Models/Allies both internally and externally, and encourage our employees to leverage LGBT Great's mentorship program. Learning & Development: EquiLend provides at least one annual LGBT+ diversity & inclusion training to all employees globally, aiming to create a workplace where everyone feels respected and valued, inclusive of their sexual orientation or gender identity. Communications (Internal/External): The Diversity & Inclusion Committee works closely with EquiLend's Marketing team to publish a consistent schedule of D&I-related content both internally and externally. Different members of the D&I Committee regularly contribute to internal newsletters on specific D&I-related themes. EquiLend's external posts on social channels publicly reflect EquiLend's commitment to championing Diversity & Inclusion and enhancing our practices.

column34: Discrimination based on sexual orientation policy: As EquiLend is a global company, our policies vary based on region, in accordance with local legislation and anti-discrimination laws. In the US, all employees must agree to the Policy Against Harassment and Discrimination and Retaliation which prohibits discrimination, acts of harassment and any other conduct that creates an intimidating, hostile or offensive work environment, or unreasonably interferes with work performance based on an individual’s actual or perceived age, race, physical characteristics historically associated with race (such as natural hair, hair texture, hair type and protective hairstyles), color, national origin or immigration status, citizenship, work authorization status or the period of such a status, ancestry, sex, gender (including pregnancy, childbirth or medical condition related to pregnancy or childbirth), reproductive health decision making, gender identity or expression, sexual orientation, religious creed, physical or mental disability, medical condition, genetic information, HIV testing status, status as a victim of a crime of violence (such as domestic, sexual, or gender violence), marital status, familial status, veteran status, military status, Civil Air Patrol status or any other characteristic protected by federal, state or local law. Discrimination based on gender identity and expression policy: As EquiLend is a global company, our policies vary based on region, in accordance with local legislation and anti-discrimination laws. In the US, all employees must agree to the Policy Against Harassment and Discrimination and Retaliation which prohibits discrimination, acts of harassment and any other conduct that creates an intimidating, hostile or offensive work environment, or unreasonably interferes with work performance based on an individual’s actual or perceived age, race, physical characteristics historically associated with race (such as natural hair, hair texture, hair type and protective hairstyles), color, national origin or immigration status, citizenship, work authorization status or the period of such a status, ancestry, sex, gender (including pregnancy, childbirth or medical condition related to pregnancy or childbirth), reproductive health decision making, gender identity or expression, sexual orientation, religious creed, physical or mental disability, medical condition, genetic information, HIV testing status, status as a victim of a crime of violence (such as domestic, sexual, or gender violence), marital status, familial status, veteran status, military status, Civil Air Patrol status or any other characteristic protected by federal, state or local law. Inclusive parental leave policy (i.e. shared maternity & parental leave): EquiLend offers gender-inclusive paid parental leave globally across all regional locations. Policies vary based on region. Adoption leave policy: EquiLend's paid parental leave policies apply identically to employees who are in the process of adoption.

column54: At EquiLend we are dedicated to attracting and supporting LGBTQ+ talent through a variety of targeted initiatives. One of those ways is by utilising language decoders to ensure that all our job advertisements are written in inclusive language, making them welcoming to LGBTQ+ candidates. In addition, we actively partner with LGBTQ+ organisations (such as yourselves) to connect with a diverse talent pool. We also provide comprehensive diversity and inclusion training to all employees, aiming to create a workplace where everyone feels respected and valued, regardless of their sexual orientation or gender identity. To further this commitment, we post externally to show our support for the LGBTQ+ community (link below) and maintain an active diversity committee. This committee plays a crucial role in ensuring that diversity is celebrated within the organisation and that these values are communicated clearly to all employees.
column57: How does your organisation seek to position itself as an LGBTQ+ inclusive employer?
column58: We ensure that our support for the LGBTQ+ community is clearly communicated both internally and externally. Our diversity committee which consists of active members from various backgrounds plays a key role in promoting and celebrating LGBTQ+ inclusion within EquiLend. Through regular communications, awareness campaigns and training, we reinforce our stance as an LGBTQ+ inclusive employer. We aim to create a welcoming environment as well as internal awareness where LGBTQ+ employees feel respected, supported, and valued, and where diversity is genuinely embraced as a strength.

column5: For each of the selected answers in Q1, please describe what responsibilities they have for LGBTQ+ DE&I in your organisation.
column6: Board – Our CEO presents a people and culture update at every Board meeting, which covers diversity matters including LGBT+. This provides the Board with oversight of employee engagement, diversity, equity and inclusion. Robyn Grew is the senior sponsor for the Pride@Man network and is very visible internally and externally in the drive for LGBT+ inclusion Executive management – our ExCo are very supportive of inclusion for all not just LGBT+ and Carol Ward, President Man Discretionary is the senior advisor of the Pride@ Man network. Members of our ExCo also make up part of our Drive (global DEI network) SteerCo. People Team (previously HR & Talent) - are strong drivers of LGBTQ+ inclusion and continue to work with employees and the Drive networks in particular to review policies in the firm. Many members of the People team are also members of the Pride@Man network. D&I – the Pride@Man Network is one of several employee resource groups at Man, who drive forward LGBT+ initiatives with the main aim of creating an environment where everyone feels comfortable to bring their true selves to the office every day. Non-executive line management- All people managers have a set of ‘expectations’ and one of these is culture and inclusion, with the responsibility to their direct reports to create an environment of tolerance, understanding and safety where everyone feels like they ‘belong’.
column9: For each of the selected stakeholder groups in Q3, please describe who they are and how they are measured against LGBTQ+ DE&I goals and objectives. Please confirm that you have the permission of the person referenced to use their name.
column10: The Board - For the CEO and CFO's bonuses 30% of the annual bonus is awarded based on qualitative ‘strategic and personal objectives' and 'ESG-related objectives' which includes DE&I measures. (pg 104 of Annual Report) DE&I Team - Our global diversity network, Drive is managed by the Corporate Sustainability Team and we take part in a number of diversity benchmarking exercises such as the Diversity Project Goals and Progress Tool and the iiBT. The annual Thriving at Work Assessment now has a strong focus on the intersectionality of diversity and wellbeing which we also believe as part of our strategy. Employee Resource Groups - The Drive networks (including Pride@Man) set themselves goals for the year that align with the 3 pillars of inclusion, recognition and community that make up our DE&I strategy.
column13: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column14: We reward employees with recognition through social media, the Pride@Man newsletter and our annual DE&I report also praises the work of networks and individuals.
column17: For each of the selected responses in Q7, please describe what proactive actions have been taken in the last 12 months by individuals and the organisation.
column18: Our CEO Robyn Grew is a proud role model for the LGBTQ+ community and has been quoted in several publications about being an out CEO. She also has an active role as a senior sponsor for Pride@Man, and continues to take part in internal events to discuss her career journey and give her thoughts on allyship and sponsorship. Information on LGBT+ employee resource group/network – Information on the Pride@Man network is issued to ALL new joiners as part of their welcome pack, it is also reiterated in the 1:1 new joiner check-ins (at 30 days and 90 days) Pride@Man also has a buddy system which lists members of the network that employees can approach for safe space conversations concerning LGBTQ+ issues and topics. All new employees are directed to all our internal policies including those related to LGBT+ eg. Gender identity, use of gender pronouns, parental leave and adoption leave. There is opportunity to engage in LGBT+ training and development. All employees can attend LGBT Great sessions, and or sign up to events and webinars put on by the Pride@Man network to raise awareness of LGBT+ matters. Our compliance training also includes Dignity and Respect at Work training which is mandatory for all employees.
column22: We highlight and celebrate our LGBTQ+ role models and allies on our Slack channels and also on the Pride@Man monthly newsletter.
column25: For each of the selected options in Q3, please describe how your LGBTQ+ DE&I strategy addresses each option.
column26: Our DEI programme has 3 pillars to advance our strategy: inclusion, recognition and community. We achieve this through educational and inclusive events, providing further education through toolkits, blogs and other forms of media; and finally through philanthropic efforts through volunteering with charities, schools, universities and other local communities. Our People team has considered the LGBT+ community for our benefits, including providing equal adoption leave benefits. The People team continue to review employee benefits each year to ensure we remain an employer of choice, and includes plans for a Transitioning at Work Policy in order to help employees going through this major life change. Our Comms teams have a process in place where they check in with relevant communities on issues that will impact them to ensure that messages are communicated appropriately, sensitively and effectively.

column62: Our recruitment efforts focus on reaching and attracting a diverse group of candidates. We have a diversity-focused recruitment policy in place to ensure that we have diverse interview panels and candidate lists across all roles. We run diversity-focused graduate recruitment events for underrepresented groups in full time education, and work with targeted university networks to enable our success in this area. We know the benefits that a diverse workforce brings and the numerous highly qualified candidates that are overlooked by traditional recruitment channels. We have therefore taken a series of steps both to recruit from the broadest pool of talent possible, and then to make sure that we retain these employees. For example, we work with LGBT Great as an active inclusion recruitment partner.

column70: At Man, you are expected to hold yourself and others to the highest standards of conduct and adhere to Man's strict zero-tolerance policy for discrimination, harassment and victimisation. "Dignity and Respect at Work" is a mandatory compliance training designed to instill Man Group's core principles, focusing on fostering an inclusive and respectful workplace environment. The course covers essential topics such as anti-discrimination and anti-harassment laws, ensuring employees are well-informed about legal frameworks and their responsibilities. Participants will gain a comprehensive understanding of Man's key policies and procedures related to these issues, including how to effectively implement them in daily interactions and decision-making processes. The training emphasizes the importance of maintaining dignity and respect among colleagues, promoting an atmosphere where all individuals feel valued and safe. A crucial component of the course is educating employees on Man's complaint reporting procedure. This ensures that any instances of discrimination or harassment are promptly addressed and resolved in accordance with the organization's standards. By understanding how to report and respond to complaints, employees can contribute to a culture of accountability and continuous improvement. Ultimately, the training aims to equip employees with the knowledge and tools necessary to apply Man's principles consistently, thereby perpetuating an inclusive and welcoming workplace. Through this course, Man Group reaffirms its commitment to creating an environment where diversity is celebrated and every employee is empowered to thrive.

column6: The responsibilities for LGBTQ+ initiatives at Moody's are distributed across various groups and individuals within the organization: Moody's board has several responsibilities regarding LGBTQ+ initiatives, which include recognizing and supporting the Pride Business Resource Groups (BRG) that advocates for a work environment respectful and supportive of LGBTQ+ professionals. The board is also involved in implementing inclusion strategies through the Moody's Diversity Council, which consists of senior leaders. This council ensures that strategic priorities are actualized with checks and balances instituted by a global executive council and regional councils in EMEA. Moreover, the board's involvement extends to supporting significant milestones such as earning a 100% from the Human Rights Campaign on its Corporate Equality Index since 2013 and being recognized as a top employer for LGBTQ+ people The Executive Leadership Team and senior leaders are involved in setting and agreeing on the LGBTQ+ inclusion strategy yearly through the strategic planning process. They are expected to demonstrate how they have increased inclusion in their teams as part of their performance management. The People Team and the Inclusion Team develop, govern, and execute the Inclusion strategy for Moody's in partnership with BRGs, leadership, Global and Regional Executive Sponsors, and every Moody's employee. They are entrusted with ensuring every person at the company feels valued and accepted. The Business Resource Groups (BRGs) are dedicated to supporting and advocating for employees from various backgrounds, including LGBTQ+ employees. They provide forums, resources, and programming to promote understanding and allyship. The Pride BRG’s mission is to advocate a work environment that respects, welcomes and supports lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and non-binary individuals, and enables them to perform to their fullest potential as well as continuing to promote the concept of being an ally. All employees are encouraged to promote an inclusive workplace culture on their teams, participate in Inclusion initiatives/BRG events..
column9: For each of the selected stakeholder groups in Q3, please describe who they are and how they are measured against LGBTQ+ DE&I goals and objectives. Please confirm that you have the permission of the person referenced to use their name.
column10: Moody's measures its LGBTQ+ inclusion progress using the Inclusion Scorecard, which is a comprehensive tool designed to track and measure the company's diversity and inclusion efforts. The scorecard includes various objectives and key results measures that are aligned with the company's strategic priorities. For instance, one of the objectives is to ensure that 85% of open positions will have a diverse slate of candidates for the first round of interviews. This is a new measure introduced to track the progress of inclusion in the hiring process. The scorecard also includes measures for the success and growth of women, empowering Business Resource Groups (BRGs) to champion the culture of inclusion, and the implementation of inclusive benefits like the Global, Gender-Neutral Parental Leave policy. The Inclusion Scorecard is connected to individual and team objectives through Moody's Grow, Perform, Succeed (GPS) objective-setting and development planning performance management approach. Employees are encouraged to work with their manager to connect their individual and team objectives to the company's strategic and operational objectives outlined on the Corporate Scorecard. The TIDE programme (Talent, Inclusion, Diversity, and Equality) likely contributes to the Inclusion Scorecard by supporting the company's commitment to creating a diverse and inclusive workplace. The specific goals and objectives of the TIDE programme would align with the broader DE&I strategy and be reviewed annually to measure progress. Overall, the Inclusion Scorecard serves as an "internal benchmark" to hold all stakeholders accountable for shared priorities and outcomes related to LGBTQ+ inclusion and broader diversity and inclusion goals.
column11: Evidence of a broad, robust and formalised process in place for measuring and assessing stakeholders' LGBTQ+ DE&I goals and objective. The Inclusion Scorecard is a particularly mature and data-driven approach which LGBT Great would like to commend Moody's for implementing.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dMon, 07 Oct 2024 09:40:06 GMT|
column13: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column14: Moody's recognizes and rewards employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I through various channels: Emails from the Chief Inclusion Officer: Employees receive emails from the Chief Inclusion Officer that may include recognition of their contributions to LGBTQ+ DE&I initiatives. Award Nominations: Employees can be nominated for internal (at BRG Summit by the Office of Inclusion) and external awards that acknowledge their efforts in promoting LGBTQ+ DE&I within the company. Attendance at Related Events: Employees are encouraged to attend events such as the British LGBT Awards and LGBT Great 'Together with Pride' event, which can serve as both a form of recognition and a means to further their understanding and support of LGBTQ+ issues. Annual BRG Summit in New York: The summit is an opportunity for Business Resource Group (BRG) members to come together, share best practices, and be recognized for their work over the past year. Promotion in the Inclusion Digest: The Inclusion Digest is a communication channel that highlights the efforts and achievements of employees in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I. Recognition Tool Launch in September: This upcoming tool will provide another platform for acknowledging and celebrating the contributions of employees to our Inclusion efforts including LGBTQ+. These initiatives demonstrate Moody's commitment to creating an inclusive environment and recognizing the valuable contributions of its employees towards LGBTQ+ diversity, equity, and inclusion.
column15: Evidence of a comprehensive and integrated approach to recognising and rewarding LGBTQ+ DE&I efforts, embedded in the Moody's culture and values and reflected in formalised performance management.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dMon, 07 Oct 2024 09:40:06 GMT|
column17: For each of the selected responses in Q7, please describe what proactive actions have been taken in the last 12 months by individuals and the organisation.
column18: The Moody's Global Inclusion Council is chaired by the CEO and includes members from Moody's Corporation Operating Committee, which is a group of senior leaders responsible for overseeing the company's operations and ensuring the implementation of its strategic goals. This committee plays a crucial role in guiding the company's direction and making key decisions that impact various aspects of the business.. Global Executive Sponsors and Regional Executive Sponsors: These senior leaders play a crucial role in advancing inclusion at Moody's. They work closely with the Inclusion team and Business Resource Groups (BRGs) to ensure that events and initiatives are aligned with the focus areas of Moody's Inclusion Strategy. Mentoring and Reverse Mentoring: We hope to reinstate our reverse mentoring programme in the coming year. Moody's collaborates with external partners such as LGBT Great. This partnership provides LGBTQ+ employees and allies with opportunities to participate in mentorship programmes that connect mentees with mentors across different regions and organizations. These programmes are designed to help participants network among peers, build confidence, and learn new skills. The collaboration with LGBT Great is part of Moody's broader effort to support LGBTQ+ talent and promote an inclusive workplace culture Internal and External Training and Coaching: The LGBTQ+ training at Moody's is designed to cultivate a supportive and understanding environment for LGBTQ+ individuals in the workplace. column34: Moody's has established several policies to ensure an inclusive and supportive work environment for all employees, including those who are LGBTQ+ or non-binary. Here are the details of the policies you've inquired about: Discrimination Based on Sexual Orientation Policy: Moody's Discrimination and Harassment Policy clearly states that discrimination and harassment, including on the basis of sexual orientation, will not be tolerated. The policy includes harassment on the basis of sex, gender, sexual orientation, gender identity, gender expression, and the status of being transgender. Discrimination Based on Gender Identity and Expression Policy: The same policy also covers discrimination and harassment based on gender identity and expression. It ensures a work environment that respects the dignity and worth of each individual and is free from all forms of employment discrimination. Transitioning at Work Policy: Moody's Gender Transition Guidelines support employees considering transitioning in the workplace. The guidelines affirm the right of employees to express their gender identity and characteristics without fear of negative consequences and recommend working closely with the People Team and management to ensure the best possible transition experience. Support for Non-Binary Employees at Work Policy: Non-binary employees are supported in expressing their gender identity and characteristics at work. Inclusive Parental Leave Policy: Moody's Global Parental Leave Policy offers a minimum of 16 weeks of paid parental leave at 100% base salary for all eligible employees who become parents, including through adoption and surrogacy, supporting diverse family structures and needs. Adoption Leave Policy: The Global Parental Leave Policy also applies to adoption, ensuring that employees who become parents through adoption receive the same level of support as other parents. Gender Expression/Transition Guide: The Gender Transition Guidelines provide best practices for transitioning employees, including the use of facilities matching their gender identity and recommendations for a smooth transition process. Moody's has a comprehensive approach to preventing discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity/expression. The Discrimination and Harassment Policy, revised as recently as July 20, 2023, ensures a work environment that respects the dignity and worth of each individual and is free from all forms of employment discrimination, including harassment because of sexual orientation, gender identity, gender expression, and other protected characteristics. This policy is supplemented by annual training on Moody's Code of Business Conduct, which includes anti-discrimination and anti-harassment training. All employees complete this mandatory training, which explicitly prohibits bullying and harassment, including on the basis of sexual orientation and gender identity/expression. The training is tracked and required annually, and non-compliance is addressed by the compliance team. Additionally, Moody's has a zero-tolerance approach towards discrimination, bullying, harassment on the basis of gender identity and gender expression, as outlined in the Trans Inclusive Guide [5]. The company also expects its suppliers to maintain a workplace free of harassment and discrimination, as stated in the Supplier Code of Conduct. If any employee feels that they have been mistreated because of homophobia, biphobia, or transphobia, they can report the matter to Moody's Integrity Hotline. The company's commitment to inclusivity is also reflected in the Moody's Code of Conduct and the UK Handbook, which all employees are required to sign and adhere to.

(Trans* is an umbrella term for people whose gender identity differs from the sex they were assigned at birth. column49: What campaigns, strategies or approaches has your organisation undertaken to improve comfort around disclosing self-ID DE&I data?
column50: To ensure employees feel comfortable sharing their self-identification data, Moody's is committed to maintaining the highest standards of data accuracy, retention, and security. The UK Self-ID Campaign outlines specific measures such as: Data Accuracy: Employee Self-Service permissions will be used to maintain data accuracy, allowing fields to be editable by the employee only and viewable by authorized roles. Data Retention: Data will be anonymized during lower instance refreshes and destroyed via DRTM purge seven years after an employee terminates, as per the annual DRTM purge conducted each December. Data Security: Role-Based Permissions will safeguard the data, ensuring that only those with appropriate access can view or edit the data. The data is not exportable unless specific permissions are granted. Furthermore, an FAQ document has been created to address common questions and concerns employees might have regarding the self-identification process. This document clarifies that self-identification is entirely voluntary and explains how to self-identify within WorkWise. It also emphasizes that diverse groups, including LGBTQ+ individuals, are at risk of being undercounted, highlighting the importance of self-identification for accurate representation and support within the company. Moody's assures that all personal data collected will be treated with the utmost confidentiality and used solely for the purpose of advancing DE&I within the organization. The information provided will not be considered in hiring or promotion decisions, ensuring that employees' privacy and professional integrity remain intact. For any further details or concerns, employees are encouraged to refer to the comprehensive Self-Identification FAQ document, which provides in-depth answers to potential queries.

It is available to all Moody’s leaders: “Inclusive Leadership: Actions You Can Take”, which provides practical steps for leaders to foster an inclusive environment at Moody's. Here are some key actions highlighted in the document. These actions are part of Moody's commitment to creating a workplace that reflects a broad range of cultures, experiences, and backgrounds. The document emphasizes that a diverse workforce bolsters the quality of products and analytical insight and strengthens the understanding of customers globally.

column117: If yes, please describe how this was achieved and attach a copy of your dress code.
column118: Moody’s UK Employee Handbook has reviewed it’s dress code to ensure that it is LGBTQ+ inclusive, when we address harassment in the workplace. Discrimination and Harassment You should refer to the “How We Treat Each Other” ” section of the “Moody’s Code of Business Conduct”. Examples of prohibited and discriminatory bullying and harassment, include: Making assumptions and judgements about a colleague based on gender identity and gender expression. For example, about their choice of dress; We also refer to choice of dress in our Trans Inclusive Guide - Those who consider themselves gender variant may change their gender expression in terms of how they like to dress, moving between the feminine and masculine ends of the spectrum. Some people also choose to not dress as feminine or masculine and are androgynous. Gender Transition Guide - We do not have a gendered dress code. This means all employees, including trans and non-binary employees can dress as they feel comfortable within the dress code to appear smart and professional. For example, any person of any gender may choose to wear skirts, trousers, make-up, etc.; or a combination thereof. LGBTQIA+ Guide - Gender reassignment: Another way of describing a person’s transition. To undergo gender reassignment usually means to undergo some sort of medical intervention, but it can also mean changing names, pronouns, dressing differently and living in their self-identified gender.
column119: Evidence of set of guidelines surrounding dress which are not just neutral but actively inclusive, flexible and avoid gender stereotypes whilst clarifying expectations to meet company and industry culture, demonstrating a very high degree of maturity in this area.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dFri, 11 Oct 2024 13:43:14 GMT|

column122: Moody's employee benefits in the UK are fully inclusive of LGBTQ+ people. Moody's is committed to fostering a diverse and inclusive culture that supports the well-being and professional growth of its employees. Eligibility for Moody’s private medical insurance is available to all employees and their partners (regardless of gender) and/or children – Taken from Moody’s UK Benefits Handbook. As above, all employees receive medical cover which can be provided to partners and dependents at a modest extra cost. The Benefits team has worked with our medical provider to ensure that it is LGBTQ+ and trans inclusive. Moody's has achieved a 100% rating on the Human Rights Campaign Corporate Equality Index, which is a testament to their commitment to LGBTQ+ workplace equality. They have also been designated as a Best Place to Work for LGBTQ Equality. One of the significant steps Moody's has taken is the implementation of a global gender-neutral parental leave policy. This policy allows all eligible employees to take up to 16 weeks of paid leave for the birth, adoption, or foster placement of a child, regardless of their gender identity or sexual orientation. This policy promotes gender equality and supports working parents at Moody's. Moody's also has a longstanding global policy of providing a work environment that respects the dignity and worth of each individual and is free from all forms of employment discrimination, including harassment, because of sexual orientation or gender identity. These inclusive benefits demonstrate Moody's commitment to creating a supportive and inclusive environment for all employees, including those who identify as LGBTQ+.

column17: For each of the selected responses in Q7, please describe what proactive actions have been taken in the last 12 months by individuals and the organisation.
column18: abrdn joined LGBT great as a member and held focus groups with Lighthouse and LGBTQ+ group for direction of travel. Reviewed transgender policy with LGBT great, set up a gig (small project working group) which looked at LGBTQ+ priorities for the network and the organisation – transgender policy review, participating in the LGBT Great benchmark. For Pride we put more focus on the support for colleagues through policies. We ran the ‘What you see and the real me’ campaign and one of the Network chairs was part of this, and it demonstrated how important it is to have a network around you. Our Lighthouse Diversity Network offers a safe space for the LGBTQ+ community to learn and grow together through sharing experiences, allyship and advocacy. All are welcome. We also have an LGBTQ+ (Lighthouse) Community on our Engage platform. June 2024 – Our Lighthouse Network posted LGBTQ Pride Month FAQs on our MS Engage platform as a means of educating our colleagues on honoring the history of Pride. We are currently working with LGBT Great to draft Transgender guidelines June 2024 - Rose Toast to Pride Month event with a collection of items for donation to the Philly AIDS Thrift Store, with proceeds distributed to local AIDS organizations. Our My Development site offers ongoing educational modules for building awareness and empathy among colleagues on DEI Topics including LGBT+ rights, inclusion and allyship. On February 14, 2024 - Go Red day celebrated the intersectionality of our people, recognizing that we are multi-faceted individuals. Our four Americas Networks came together, wearing red to celebrate the intersection of culture, health and for the LGBTQ community, “Love is Love” in honor of LGBT+ History Month in the US. DEI Book Club (see below – also external training) Our Balance Network hosts a bi-weekly Parent Meet-up Group to provide a safe space for parents to meet and discuss a wide range of topic around raising children; and is co-sponsoring our August event on talking to our children about LGBTQ+ External Training and/or Coaching July 2024 - Our DEI Book Club invites all colleagues to engage in reading books on DEI topics and creates a safe space for growing in awareness and perspectives together. On July 1st, we announced our next selection as “Raising LGBTQ Allies: A Parent’s Guide to Changing the Messages from the Playground” by Chris Tompkins. We have contracted with the author to host a webinar to present his story and to answer questions our colleagues may have on 8/15/24, following which we will read his book in our Book Club format with weekly open discussions. We participated in the 2024 Human Rights Campaign Corporate Equality Index Survey, scoring 95/100%. This includes being scored in comparison to external organizations on We partner with Powered By Diversity to offer Diversity Networks a catalogue of events which include opportunities for webinars on a variety of DEI Topics throughout the year. Our benefits partner Aon also offers a catalogue of wellness webinars, one of which was on suicide prevention which educated colleagues on issues and stats surrounding LGBT+ youth. Our Capability Network utilized Mental Health America’s Toolkit for Mental Health Awareness in the Month in May, which brought awareness to some issues facing the LGBT+ community. We partnered for multiple events with The Human Library to educate and bring awareness and empathy to colleagues through engagement with those who are willing to share personal stories and hold safe space Q&A sessions. Some of the human “Books” identify as LGBTQ+. Executive sponsorship opportunities for LGBTQ+ DE&I/ERG We are currently undergoing a DEI Reset which included active listening sessions and other discovery around our DEI strategy and initiatives and tying them to our overall corporate strategy. This includes Executive Leadership Team-agreed sponsorship of our Global Diversity Networks. The DEI Reset also includes DEI Awareness training for our Leaders and People Managers by an external third party.
column19: LGBT Great would like to commend Abrdn on this fantastic range of initiatives and achievements - well done!-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dMon, 23 Sep 2024 14:09:57 GMT|
column22: We have a DEI network - Lighthouse (LGBTQ+ and allies) and the DEI Network is on Engage. Benjamin Brust our Hd of General Counsel's Office and Jonny Black Chief Commercial & Strategy Officer are current sponsors of our lighthouse network with further discussions ongoing for Exec-level sponsorship. Both Jonny and Benjamin through their work in the network have written blogs or been visible role models of the community. This has so far been primarily occasional blogs and use of Viva Engage, however following the DEI reset and National Inclusion week will be ramped up. The ”What you see and The real me” campaign continues to highlight colleagues from different backgrounds. One of our Lighthouse co-chairs featured in the first 7 stories of this campaign where he discusses acceptance and the strength of LGBTQ+ communities and networks in organisations. This post received just over 3000 views on Viva engage, over 1000 views on our intranet homepage (still generating views 2 months after posting) while receiving moving comments on both. This campaign with other stories highlights colleagues with different stories and encourages sharing, allyship, and more.
column23: Great work, the ”What you see and The real me” is a fantastic initiative.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dMon, 23 Sep 2024 14:09:57 GMT|
column25: For each of the selected options in Q3, please describe how your LGBTQ+ DE&I strategy addresses each option.
column26: L&D is provided through various platforms – please see answer 7 for further information for how our L&D strategy encompasses DEI. Currently on our people system we collect Sexual Orientation data, Gender Identity data (both as binary M/F as required by benefits and local tax) and as inclusive options. We also collect Pronoun usage. This is collected in all locations for which we are able to legally collect the data. This is analysed regularly and on an ad-hock basis for both reporting purposes and for reviewing during change – such as allowing analysis through part of our employee surveys, and when LGBTQ+ topics are on the agenda – such as during key events like National Inclusion week. Communications are done as employee-led via our global lighthouse committee, via specific events from partners such as the previously mentioned benefits or speaker series which have been run, and finally through the central comms team during key events. National inclusion week is being coordinated via the colleague experience team in 2024 including a robust ahead of time, during, and post colleague comms plan covering data, employee involvement, myths and misconceptions, and network information.
column27: Awarding partial credit as although Abrdn does not have a centralised LGBTQ+ DE&I strategy per se, it is evident that your Global DE&I includes LGBTQ+ specificity with measurable outputs.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dTue, 24 Sep 2024 13:05:48 GMT|
column29: If yes, please provide details of the process and which stakeholder is accountable for it? Please ensure that you have the permission of the person referenced to use their name.
column30: While we do not have a formal written process in place, as referred to previously we do collect data around LGBTQ+ from colleagues which is reviewed to monitor impact and change. This includes regular reporting in which general direction of travel can be noted and analysed. We also review data completion rates to check the improvement in data disclosure dependent on various initiatives. For example since May 2024 and the refocus on both data collection and storytelling via What you see and The real me, we have seen a not-seen-before increase in data completion rates overall of 11% increase in just 3 months. While we currently are working at implementing a robust career framework and formalising promotion definition and process (following a period of change as an organisation) once this has been completed will gain the ability to accurately and consistently analyse colleague levels, promotions, and movers through different lenses (including LGBTQ+) which will allow (alongside the increased disclosure) a clear measure and monitor of progress and initiative impact.

column45: How does your organisation utilise sexual orientation and gender identity diversity data to improve LGBTQ+ DE&I?

column49: What campaigns, strategies or approaches has your organisation undertaken to improve comfort around disclosing self-ID DE&I data?
column50: The organisation ran the ‘2mins to make a difference’ campaign, asking all employees to update their Workday data (the organisations people system) to make abrdn a better place to work for everyone. This included the production of a short video to help colleagues understand how to complete their data and what it was used for, it included a reinforce of the data in the majority of company emails and messages for Q2/3 2024, and has also included specific ELT members and their business areas doing messaging. This included within an all-HR townhall, a personal note from our Group General Counsel to the legal and secretariat function, and reference and personal note from our CIO to his function. The ”What you see and The real me” campaign continues to highlight colleagues from different backgrounds. On of our Lighthouse co-chairs featured in the first 7 stories of this campaign where he discusses acceptance and the strength of LGBTQ+ communities and networks in organisations. This post received just over 3000 views on Viva engage, over 1000 views on our intranet homepage (still generating views 2 months after posting) while receiving moving comments on both. column53: How does your organisation target and attract LGBTQ+ talent?
column54: We purposefully design our recruitment marketing to be as inclusive and diverse as possible. We publish LGBTQ+ specific content in support and celebration of Pride (example below), which is visible to over 177k followers on LinkedIn, many of whom a previous and prospective candidates and job applicants. Where we post video content, we aim to ensure that we have diverse representation from hiring teams to further cement our commitment to creating a place of work where the authentic self is valued and encouraged. All of our job adverts contain an inclusivity statement with further links into our D,E,I commitments: Our Inclusive Culture We are committed to exploring the possibilities of working smarter. This means we’d like to hear from you, whatever way you like to work. We have a long-term commitment to building inclusive workplaces; we value diversity in our workforce and welcome enquiries from everyone. If you need assistance or a reasonable adjustment due to a disability please let us know as part of your application and we will assist. You can find out more about our inclusive culture here. In addition, as part of our onboarding, candidates receive information about all of our employee networks, including our LGBTQ+ network, Lighthouse.
column55: It is encouraging to see the range of initiatives Abrdn uses to attract LGBTQ+ talent, however LGBTQ+ specificity can be enhanced through targeted LGBTQ+ outreach efforts, such as engaging with LGBT Great Careers as a part of your membership. This could be an area of strategic focus for 2025.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dTue, 24 Sep 2024 17:09:52 GMT|
column57: How does your organisation seek to position itself as an LGBTQ+ inclusive employer?
column58: We intentionally publish and promote content on key dates but for us diversity and inclusion is at the heart of everything we do, every day! From recruitment marketing content to intake calls with managers where our recruiters seek to understand the composition of existing teams and provide input and constructive challenge around diversity gaps, to the close relationships we seek to form with our candidates as part of our interview and offer processes. We seek to understand what is important to people engaged in our processes and their concerns so that we can allay any concerns and connect them to relevant resources within our organisation from the offset.

column74: We are committed to building a diverse supply base.
