column5: For each of the selected answers in Q1, please describe what responsibilities they have for LGBTQ+ DE&I in your organisation.
column6: Executive Committee: Our LGBTQ+ Employee Network is supported by an ExCo sponsor dedicated to advocating for the network's initiatives and LGBTQ+ matters. This sponsor plays a pivotal role in securing support from the Executive Committee and senior management, helping to foster a company-wide culture of inclusivity. They act as a role model for being an ally and championing inclusive behaviours. They help to raise the profile of the employee networks and get buy in and support from the rest of the executive committee as needed. Non-Executive Management The driving forces from within this stakeholder group are the I&D committee, co-chaired by Ben Bramhall, our co-CEO, and Charlotte West, Head of Employee Engagement. This committee is tasked with shaping our overarching I&D strategy and overseeing its implementation. Formed of representatives from across our business functions and the network chairs, the committee draws on a wide range of perspectives to manage a comprehensive I&D programme. This programme addresses inclusion related to gender, ethnicity, disability and LGBTQ+ communities, alongside mental health and wellbeing. The I&D committee holds our employee networks accountable for achieving their strategic objectives and bi-annually reports their progress to the plc Board. Human Resources + D&I HR is responsible for facilitating the implementation of key initiatives, particularly around policies and process. Working in tandem with the networks, HR reviews these annually to ensure continuous improvement in fostering a fully inclusive environment. As part of our organisational structure, the D&I function falls within scope of the Employee Engagement Team which reports up to the HR Director. The team supports the employee networks, lends expertise on maximising the effectiveness of resource groups, orchestrates events and educational activities, and facilitates cross-functional collaboration for business-wide change. They set the standard for inclusive behaviour and work to maintain the visibility and buy-in of our DEI agenda through consistent communication and internal networking. Collaboration between HR and the Employee Engagement team is also key in delivering inclusion training to all line managers and new colleagues. Network Chairs The chairs of our Employee Networks (employee resource groups) are responsible for working with the wider network and business to establish a strategy for the year which identifies: • Priorities - key focus areas for the year • Objectives • Actions to achieve the defined objectives • Appropriate KPIs With the support of the EE Team, the Network chairs ensure the strategy is delivered across the year. There are also role models for inclusive behaviours and act as champions for all DE&I activity taking place across the business.
column9: For each of the selected stakeholder groups in Q3, please describe who they are and how they are measured against LGBTQ+ DE&I goals and objectives. Please confirm that you have the permission of the person referenced to use their name.
column10: All Employees We have 5 organisational objectives that all employees are expected to demonstrate they are meeting through the year. There is a specific objective on Inclusion and Diversity which aims to create a holistically inclusive environment rather than targeting any group or category. The objective is worded as follows: “Everyone has the responsibility of making XPS a great place to work. We all have responsibility for actively promoting equality of opportunity, acting in line with our values and providing colleagues with the opportunity to share their ideas, views, and concerns.” The Employee Engagement Team Each network has a dedicated Employee Engagement Team lead. The Employee Engagement Team member then has specific objectives aligned to the delivery of key actions relating to the delivery of the network strategies they are linked to. Employee Resource Groups The employee resource groups are assessed annually by the I&D committee on what they have delivered over the year. With published strategies, action plans and KPIs for the year, these are used to track their impact. Performance by the networks then influence the budgets available to them in future years. Network chairs and members may also have individual objectives aligned to their contributions to these networks that they have agreed with their line managers. There is currently no expectation that this is done and so is down to individuals. Executive Committee While the Executive team don’t have specific LGBTQ+ Goals, they are held to account for the progress of our overall I&D strategy with their pay linked to this.
column13: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column14: Performance against organisational objectives and objectives relating to LGBTQ+ DE&I will impact an individual’s performance rating and therefore their bonus potential in the year. We also hold an annual employee award to recognise those that go above and beyond in demonstrating our values and championing inclusivity. Our nominees are all recognised for their contributions to XPS by a Teams call by one of the ExCo, while winners are recognised publicly across the business for their efforts, along with receiving a monetary award and trophy. See supporting evidence iiBT 01 for a screenshot of the intranet page announcing winners. Recognising the importance of role models, we celebrate the people who champion inclusion at XPS by sharing their employee stories internally and on social media. Network efforts are called out and acknowledged by the co-CEOs in their weekly voice notes to the whole business when they launch any new initiative or host an event (see supporting evidence iiBT 02). The employees who contributed in particular to specific initiatives and events also receive a thank you by the ExCo sponsor
column17: For each of the selected responses in Q7, please describe what proactive actions have been taken in the last 12 months by individuals and the organisation.
column18: In the last 12 months, we’ve delivered a number of actions aimed at building leadership and management understanding and awareness of LGBTQ+ issues. Key events have included: • Launching our three-part training series in collaborating with LGBT Great on Inclusive Language, Privilege and Allyship. • Hosting Freddy McConnell as a guest speaker to share his experiences of being transgender in the workplace, and the importance of inclusive practices and policies, drawing in particular from his experiences of being pregnant. • Providing line manager training on inclusion • Using the line manager Teams channel to share information and context around the launch of our Trans, Non-binary and Intersex inclusion policy and open up options for questions • Promoting LGBT Great Events internally and encouraging people to attend if possible • Including regular communications in the XPS Weekly News Update containing awareness information about key LGTBQ+ issues or topics (e.g. the importance of non-binary people’s day)
column25: For each of the selected options in Q3, please describe how your LGBTQ+ DE&I strategy addresses each option.
column26: We focus on LGBTQ+ Talent retention and attraction through: • Building a community and safe space for LGBTQ+ employees to connect with each other • Collaborating with HR to develop inclusive policies and working practices • Educating the business on key LGBTQ+ issues so that we can ensure we have an inclusive environment • Promoting visible allyship with the use of pronouns and rainbow lanyards • Showcasing our commitment to inclusion on our social media channels and website We focus on Learning and Development for LGBTQ+ by offering both an internal mentoring scheme and the option to take part in the LGBT Great’s mentoring programme. Our internal mentoring scheme is open to all colleagues and not specific to LGBTQ+ colleagues, however mentors and mentees can request to be matched with another LGBTQ+ colleague. Our other L&D initiatives are available to all colleagues and include soft skills training delivered in-house, technical training opportunities, and both soft and technical online training courses. We are starting to look at how we can capture better LGBTQ+ Data and ROI information on relevant initiatives and events. We are currently looking at engagement with LGBTQ+ content vs. other DE&I content vs. general updates, getting feedback on all internal events, and encouraging employees to share their personal information on our HR system so we can track representation across our business areas and job grades. On communication, our strategy focuses on ensuring that language is inclusive and that we increase the visibility of the LGBTQ+ Network and relevant topics.
column29: If yes, please provide details of the process and which stakeholder is accountable for it? Please ensure that you have the permission of the person referenced to use their name.
column30: We conduct an annual review of the network strategy, looking at the feedback that has been received through our engagement surveys and network to identify key areas of focus. The KPIs set for the year (and outlined in the LGBTQ+ strategy deck) are checked periodically so that we can ensure to promote activities and initiatives that will help us meet those targets. Regular updates are provided to the I&D committee and wider network on progress. During general network discussions, we encourage regular feedback and input into our events and initiatives to ensure that we are doing things that work for our employees.
column33: For each of the selected options in Q6, please list the policy and provide supporting commentary. Please attach a copy of the policies.
column34: We don’t have a specific policy with each of the titles above, however we have a few separate polices which aim to cover the same topics: I&D Policy (iiBT 04) + Bullying and Harassment Prevention policy (iiBT 05) These policies set out expected behaviours for treating all employees with dignity and respect. It also ensures that everyone is explicitly aware that discrimination of any sort is not tolerated. The policies also outline the steps to report non-inclusive behaviour. Transgender, non-binary and intersex inclusion policy (iiBT 06) This policy covers transitioning at work and support that any of our transgender, non-binary and intersex colleagues may need. We also reference our Menopause policy and Health and Menopause network to support from a hormonal changes perspective. Family Friendly Leave Policy (iiBT 07) To make things easier for colleagues to find, and recognising different family units, we cover all family leave polices in one document which includes: • Share parental leave • Adoption • Maternity • Paternity Gender Expression (iiBT 21) We don't currently have a specific policy on gender expression, however we do have a guide about the value of sharing pronouns, and cover elements about gender expression in our transgender, non-binary and intersex inclusion policy. All our policies are independently reviewed either by our partner organisations (e.g. LGBT Great for LGBTQ+ related policies, or by the Inclusive Group - our external DEI consultants.
column37: If yes, please specify what questions are asked and what options are available to your employees.
column38: Our HR system has a section where employees can share their sensitive information. Questions are positioned as section headings. i.e. Just reads 'Sexual Orientation'. Options available to employees are: Bi, Decline to specify, Gay, Heterosexual, Lesbian, Other, Prefer not to say. The question is entirely voluntary.
column41: If yes, please specify what questions are asked and what options are available to your employees.
column42: We collect this data as part of our gender identity data collection. Due to limitations in the way we can phrase and ask questions on our HR system, we worked with the LGBTQ+ Network to identify a way to capture diversity data in a way they felt comfortable and worked within the system constraints. The options to respond to the gender identity questions are as follows: • Female (cis) • Female (trans) • Intersex • Male (cis) • Male (trans) • Non-binary / Other gender non-conforming. HR and the network continue to work together to explore options to improve the way data is collected and the options presented to be as inclusive as possible while working within the current third-party system constraints.
column45: How does your organisation utilise sexual orientation and gender identity diversity data to improve LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column46: It is the early days of collecting data, so we don’t currently act on the information to a significant extent at the moment. Primary uses of the data are to help us understand: • Areas to focus on (e.g. topics and subjects that will impact a greater percentage of our employee population) • Establish a baseline for representation across different business functions and job grades to enable us to track impact on future initiatives targeting recruitment, career development etc.
column49: What campaigns, strategies or approaches has your organisation undertaken to improve comfort around disclosing self-ID DE&I data?
column50: Have run a couple of count me in campaigns encouraging employees to share their sensitive information over the last few months to explain the business case for it collecting DE&I Data. We also share information about how the data is used, how things are kept confidential and who has access to the information. We also specifically call out where the data is not used (e.g. in making decisions about an individual person, as part of performance appraisals etc.) Attached is one example of the promo materials we’ve used to encourage employees to share their data (iiBT 08 - Diversity Data Poster)
column53: How does your organisation target and attract LGBTQ+ talent?
column54: Don’t currently have a strategy in place to specifically target and attract LGBTQ+ talent. We focus primarily on showcasing XPS as an inclusive employer, covering all aspects of DEI inclusion. More details are covered in response to the next question.
column57: How does your organisation seek to position itself as an LGBTQ+ inclusive employer?
column58: This is done primarily through the way we promote our employer brand on social media and our website. We currently showcase the following: • Our employee networks • Our commitment to inclusion • Our people • The benefits we offer We also look to showcase employee stories frequently, highlighting role models, and people with different lived experiences. Attached are screenshots from our LinkedIn page: • iiBT 09 - Screenshot of the Company Spotlights from our LinkedIn Life page • iiBT 10 - Pride LinkedIn post (url) • iiBT 11 - Our people approach website page (url) • iiBT 12 - Life at XPS website page (url)
column61: If yes, please name the policy and/or actions that your organisation is taking to reduce bias in the recruitment process and support for line managers.
column65: For each of the selected responses in Q6, what action was taken, and what outcomes were achieved over the last 12 months?
column66: Our attraction focus over the last 12 months has been focused on achieving our targets surrounding gender and ethnicity. So we haven’t taken actions focused specifically on LGBTQ+ talent attraction within the last 12 months. We explored the possibility of advertising key roles on the LGBT great career platform which would have been a great opportunity, however our legal team were not comfortable with a few of the terms that couldn’t be changed, and so we decided not to proceed with that option at this stage. While we haven’t targeted LGBTQ+ attraction specifically, we have taken various measures to showcase our approach to inclusion at XPS and our commitment to welcoming and encouraging people of all backgrounds. We’ve done so by sharing social media posts in recognition of key LGBTQ+ days, promoting the launch of our Trans, Non-binary and Intersex Inclusion policy, and employee stories. We also have an employee referral programme where employees are paid up to £2,500 for recommending a successful candidate in a role. The employee making the recommendation receives a first £1,000 payment when the new employee joins, and a second £1,500 payment once the new employee successfully completes probation.
column69: Please describe and attach examples of the content covered by this training.
column70: We provide mandatory DE&I training to all new joiners and specific workshops on 'inclusive leadership' to all line managers. This focuses on respectful behaviours and understanding unconscious bias, learning to mitigate the negative effects of how we judge each other and how to promote and encourage inclusive behaviour. This training is delivered by an external provider. In addition, we host voluntary training webinars specific to LGBTQ+ inclusion throughout the year. This may come in the form of specific training, guest speakers or panel discussions. More details on these are covered in response to question 2.

column85: If yes, please attach a copy of the strategy.
column86: Our LGBTQ+ Network has a communication plan to promote visibility of the network and raise awareness and understanding of LGBTQ+ topics and issues. (iiBT 17) These comms include: • Regular content shared on our intranet and through our weekly news updates. These generally focus on awareness days, communicating our initiatives and explaining the context around them. • Inclusion of LGBTQ+ topics in the weekly CEO voice notes sent to the organisation (iiBT 02) • Updates through a general I&D Network newsletter shared bi-annually (iiBT 18 - screenshot of the LGBTQ+ section of the newsletter) • Promotion of LGBTQ+ related events and activities through social media (iiBT 10 - example LinkedIn post) The network also helps provide feedback on other company communications to help ensure they are inclusive.
column89: If yes, please describe the process.
column90: Policy Process Existing policies are reviewed annually by HR. This review process includes consulting with key stakeholders across the business, including the diversity networks to ensure that our policies are inclusive and meet the needs of our employees. Over the last 12 months, recommendations made from a LGBTQ+ perspective have included: • Updating the wording in our dress code policy to be more explicit about enabling people to dress in a way which aligns with their gender identity regardless of biological sex, or the way they may present. • Including a clause in our absence policy to ensure that gender affirming care does not count towards short-term absence triggers • Reviewing the menopause policy which also covers significant hormone change and made recommendations for how this can be more inclusive towards anyone receiving hormone treatment or going through changes (and not just those experiencing menopause symptoms) For new policies, such as for our newly launched Transgender, Non-Binary, and Intersex Inclusion policy, we go through several rounds of drafting and gathering feedback from key stakeholders to ensure the content and language is inclusive. Stakeholders include: • Policy users • Line managers • Subject matter experts (from both relevant internal teams such as HR, IT and Compliance, and external partners) Internal Communications Our internal comms go through a review and sign-off process before being sent out to colleagues so that we can check to ensure language is inclusive throughout. Where comms are particularly sensitive, we consult with key stakeholders to ensure that we do the right thing for our employees, in line with our values and approach to DE&I.
column93: If yes, please list the organisations.
column94: XPS also partner with: • Business in the Community (BITC), • Evenbreak, • Business Disability Forum, • Diversity Project, • Girls are Investors (GAIN), • Henpicked In addition to the partnerships above, we are signatories on both the Women in Finance Charter and Race at Work Charter and are a Menopause Friendly Accredited organisation.
column97: If yes, please list the awards.
column98: Recently we have achieved the following: • Women in Pensions 2024 finalist for the Organisational Award for Supporting Diversity (winners to be announced later in the year) • Shortlisted for Best DE&I Initiative at the 2024 Business Culture Awards (winners to be announced later this year) • Won best DE&I Initiative at the 2024 UK Company Culture Awards • Won the Diversity and Inclusion Excellence Award at the UK Pensions Awards 2023
column101: For each of the selected responses in Q2, please provide examples of the actions taken.
column102: Social Media We shared some of LGBTQ+ activities on our LinkedIn page to help showcase our commitment to inclusion. Posts on our LinkedIn page cover a blend of business, employee engagement and D&I activity. An example post from Pride is included. Training: The network has used a mix of blog posts, articles, webinars and guest speakers to raise awareness and understanding of the importance of: * Inclusive language (attached is one of the documents created to help with including pronouns in email signatures - IIBT 21) * Transgender, non-binary and intersex inclusion * LGBTQ+ History (in the last 12 months focusing in particular on same-sex marriage (iiBT 20) and same-sex marriage legislation around the world and in different cultures) * Intersectionality * Allyship Mentoring We welcome all XPS employees to take part in our annual internal mentoring scheme. While open to all employees, mentors and mentees can request to be paired with another LGBTQ+ colleague if possible. We also promote the opportunity to get involved with LGBT Great's mentoring programme on the networks intranet page and during network meetings. Partnering with external LGBTQ+ Organisations. Since establishing the network we have sought to partner with external organisations to help maximise our impact as a network and benefit from their expertise. We've previously partnered with Stonewall until we decided that the partnership with LGBT Great would be more beneficial. Podcasts We host an internal podcast, run on alternate months which explores different topics relating to inclusion. These are co-hosted with representatives from the other diversity networks at XPS and aim to raise the visibility of all the networks, the role of intersectionality, and the importance of allyship.
column105: For each of the selected responses in Q2, please provide examples of the actions taken.
column109: If yes, please provide examples of how this is achieved.
column110: We encourage the visibility of allies by hosting training sessions on allyship (our next to be delivered by LGBT Great in November), sharing tips and guidance on how to be an ally and encouraging to display their allyship. We have pronoun badges and rainbow lanyards available in all offices and also encourage colleagues to share their pronouns on teams, their outlook signatures and when introducing themselves if they feel comfortable. We also ensure that everyone knows that sharing pronouns is optional so that there is no judgement around not using them so that we avoid the risk of accidentally forcing people to either out themselves or misgender themselves.
column113: If yes, please provide examples of how this is achieved.
column114: We actively encourage all XPS employees to be themselves and bring their whole selves to work. Through the LGBTQ+ Network we encourage members to share their stories, make themselves visible in their local offices, champion LGBTQ+ Network events and initiatives.
column117: If yes, please describe how this was achieved and attach a copy of your dress code.
column118: We have a dress and appearance policy of “Dress for your role - Dress for your day” which allows flexibility for people to wear what is most comfortable and appropriate for the needs of their day. (iiBT 22) Following the development and launch of our transgender, non-binary and intersex inclusion policy in Jan / Feb 2024 we have made a recommendation for the wording in the dress and appearance policy to be explicitly inclusive regarding dressing in alignment with one’s gender identity. The new wording will take effect from November 2024 when the policy is next officially reviewed and republished in line with HR policy review calendar.
column121: If yes, please describe how this was achieved and attach copies of your benefits.
column122: We have developed a flexible benefit scheme where employees can pick and choose the benefits that fit their lifestyles best with benefits under the following categories • Health and Wellbeing • Finance & Protection • Lifestyle These benefits are all fully inclusive and we add to our offering based on feedback received through our employee engagement survey and our employee networks. Attached is our employee benefits booklet providing a high level overview of all benefits offered (iiBT 23).

column9: For each of the selected stakeholder groups in Q3, please describe who they are and how they are measured against LGBTQ+ DE&I goals and objectives. Please confirm that you have the permission of the person referenced to use their name.
column10: Managers across the business are encouraged to carry out informal reviews regularly throughout the year and all staff, including our Executive Committee have a formal annual appraisal for the purpose of reviewing performance over the previous year and setting goals and targets for the year ahead. There is an emphasis on the ‘how’ objectives were achieved as well as the ‘what’, requiring appraiser and appraisee to comment on how the Artemis cultural principles have been demonstrated through their behaviours. The annual appraisal is also used as an opportunity to assess individual fitness and propriety for Senior Managers and Certified staff. However, as above, the Executive Committee do not have specific objectives related to individual strands and therefore there is not a LGBT+ specific objective, nor are there LGBT+ specific objectives within any other stakeholder groups. As our work in DEI matures, we know that the objectives and how they are measured, will have to evolve to match our progress
column11: As outlined, no LGBTQ+ specificity in goals and objectives as yet. An area of strategic focus for Artemis throughout the year ahead could be establishing measurable LGBTQ+ specific goals and objectives to further underpin growing LGBTQ+ DE&I maturity.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dWed, 02 Oct 2024 12:12:43 GMT|
column13: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column14: All partners and employees are incentivised and rewarded in relation to their contribution to the business. Our Executive Committee members are rewarded based on their contribution to the business, which is assessed on an ongoing basis, and in the annual appraisal, as described in question 4. Performance is measured against objectives and assessed on the bases of what has been delivered as well as how it has been delivered. There are no LGBT+ specific recognition or rewards.
column15: Again, no LGBTQ+ specificity as yet.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dWed, 02 Oct 2024 12:12:43 GMT|
column17: For each of the selected responses in Q7, please describe what proactive actions have been taken in the last 12 months by individuals and the organisation.
column18: Michael Browning, the lead of our Sexual Orientation work strand of the DEI working group, approached the group with a plan for Pride month activities. This was approved and went ahead. We hope to continue and build on proactive support in this, and other, DEI areas going forward.
column19: This is a good start! LGBT Great can support Artemis in implementing further measures to support leadership in understanding LGBTQ+ issues such as engagement in our mentoring programme, insights training and calendar of events.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dWed, 02 Oct 2024 12:12:43 GMT|
column25: For each of the selected options in Q3, please describe how your LGBTQ+ DE&I strategy addresses each option.
column26: As before, we do not have an LGBT+ DEI strategy, however our wider work in DEI will support this indirectly. Examples of how our actions will address some of the above options: • Working with recruitment consultants and head-hunters who actively promote diverse candidates. Our interview process is more standardised, with increased HR involvement and challenge. • Taking a more coordinated approach to learning and development and leveraging specific programmes to support diverse talent. Examples include mentoring for female talent through the 30% club, targeted training for managers on policy and process, including recruitment (run by the HR team) and soft skills in conjunction with a specialist provided. • Supporting the pipeline of talent through active engagement with partners who specialise in working with young people in education (second and third level) to raise the profile of the investment management industry as an attractive career choice. We have built relationships with partners who work to raise the profile of the industry among underrepresented groups including girls and young people from socio economic groups that may not have been aware of the investment industry. These include Future Asset, Arrival Education, and Investment 20/20. We are also signing up to internship programmes through Girls Are Investors (GAIN) and 10,000 Black Interns As outlined in the above examples, we are hoping to increase the diverse talent available to us while also increasing knowledge internally that builds an inclusive culture where people of all backgrounds, orientations, gender, other beliefs, are supported and embraced.
column27: We are looking forward to seeing Artemis' centralised DE&I strategy evolve to specifically address the unique challenges and needs of LGBTQ+ employees by implementing some of the elements outlined in Q3 and as outlined above. LGBT Great are happy to support this as part of your membership.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dWed, 02 Oct 2024 12:56:10 GMT|

column45: How does your organisation utilise sexual orientation and gender identity diversity data to improve LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column46: From our current point, working to encourage more staff to anonymously report on their sexual orientation through our staff survey is the first step to improving LGBT+ DEI at Artemis. An increase in those feeling comfortable to disclose this information anonymously has shown that safety in disclosure has improved. To note that through our current anonymity settings, five people must pick the same answer before it is reportable back to us. Therefore, depending on our demographic breakdown, we may never see a representative sample of staff who are LGBTQ+ through the anonymous survey reporting tool
column47: Comprehensive approach to data capture and analysis demonstrated with clear connections between data insights and specific actions taken which aim to improve LGBTQ+ DE&I in future.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dWed, 02 Oct 2024 13:07:17 GMT|
column49: What campaigns, strategies or approaches has your organisation undertaken to improve comfort around disclosing self-ID DE&I data?
column50: Before we started to collect the data, we explained to staff via emails and staff calls why we were doing so and how it would help. Also, whenever one of the workstreams has delivered an event or there is a DEI communication to staff, we have again encouraged them to disclose this data.
column51: Evidence of some specific actions taken to improve comfort around disclosure.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dWed, 02 Oct 2024 13:07:17 GMT|
column53: How does your organisation target and attract LGBTQ+ talent?
column54: While we do not actively target LGBT+ talent, we have reviewed and refined our recruitment approach to ensure that we attract and approach a diverse range of candidates. We have committed to take active steps to hire, develop and retain a diverse workforce. Examples of some of the actions include: • Working with recruitment consultants and head-hunters who actively promote diverse candidates. Our interview process is more standardised, with increased HR involvement and challenge. • Supporting the pipeline of talent through active engagement with partners who specialise in working with young people in education (second and third level) to raise the profile of the investment management industry as an attractive career choice. We have built relationships with partners who work to raise the profile of the industry among underrepresented groups including girls and young people from socio economic groups that may not have been aware of the investment industry. These include Future Asset, Arrival Education, and Investment 20/20. We are also signing up to internship programmes through Girls Are Investors (GAIN) and 10,000 Black Interns. While these do not specifically target LGBT+ talent, we hope that by broadening the net we will see an increase of talent across all of the DEI strands. Earlier this year, during Pride month, we organised internal and external initiatives to raise awareness of LGBT+ issues. Our logo was changed for the whole month on our website. The video message posted on LinkedIn from our CIO was specifically related to pride month and we hope highlighted Artemis' commitment to DEI to potential future employees.
column55: It is great to learn about the range of DE&I initiatives that Artemis has implemented attract diverse talent, however there is little evidence of LGBTQ+ specificity provided here which limits maturity from an LGBTQ+ lens in this area. LGBT Great can help you with this as part of your membership.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dWed, 02 Oct 2024 14:21:46 GMT|
column57: How does your organisation seek to position itself as an LGBTQ+ inclusive employer?
column58: The initiatives run during Pride 2022, positioning Artemis as an LGBT+ inclusive employer, were the first of their kind at the firm. Until that point, while we had outlined our commitment to DEI on the website (https://www.artemisfunds.com/en/about-artemis/diversity-and-inclusion) we had not run a campaign that related directly to Artemis being an LGBT+ inclusive employer before. In fact, this was the first campaign run like this relating to Artemis being an inclusive employer more generally. On an ongoing basis, our commitment to DEI is outlined on the firm website and the third parties we work with or are members of (including LGBT Great) are outlined under what we do as an employer, and our subsequent commitments.
column59: Evidence of messaging on LGBTQ+ inclusion, specific content namely the video featuring Paras Anand on the website and LGBTQ+ focussed employer branding. We are happy to discuss ways of improving the scale and scope of these initiatives with Artemis as part of your membership.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dWed, 02 Oct 2024 14:21:46 GMT|

column5: For each of the selected answers in Q1, please describe what responsibilities they have for LGBTQ+ DE&I in your organisation.
column6: Nearly all of the Executive Committee members are involved in the various Networks making up Jupiter’s wide-ranging DE&I areas of focus. For Jupiter's Pride Network specifically, our sponsor attends the regular Jupiter Pride meetings and some events. They provide their views and comments on behalf of the Jupiter Pride Network for various events, forums, and other initiatives. By having an active senior sponsor, this helps us to promote Jupiter as a safe space for the LGBT+ community. They act as a conduit between the Network and the Strategy and Management Committee, raising issues any issues or concerns that the Network may have. They also act as an escalation point for any challenges or blockers that the Network may face in achieving their goals.
column9: For each of the selected stakeholder groups in Q3, please describe who they are and how they are measured against LGBTQ+ DE&I goals and objectives. Please confirm that you have the permission of the person referenced to use their name.
column10: See above. In addition, Network members and sponsors are encouraged to include their activity in their annual objectives.
column13: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column14: Jupiter takes a broad approach to celebrating individuals who play a significant role in upholding our unique culture. This includes: Proud awards: a monetary award of £1000 given on a monthly basis to individuals who have gone above and beyond to support Jupiter’s culture. In 2023, Claire Mediene and David Bone (previous Chairs of the Pride Network) were nominated and won the award for their exceptional efforts in driving forward the actions of the Pride Network. CEO ‘Cultural Ambassadors’ event – run for the first time at the start of 2024, individuals including all Network Chairs and other individuals who have made a significant contribution to Jupiter’s culture were invited to a celebratory evening hosted by Matt Beesley to recognise their significant contributions. Mett Beesley, CEO, Chairs the DE&I Forum at Jupiter, giving him an opportunity to hear first hand about the work of the Networks, and give them enhanced visibility and recognition in the firm. All Networks have an allocated budget that they are empowered and trusted to spend on activities that promote the agenda of the Network. Whilst this is not individual recognistion, it recognised the importance of the Networks and their abilities in defining an annual plan.
column17: For each of the selected responses in Q7, please describe what proactive actions have been taken in the last 12 months by individuals and the organisation.
column18: We have run two training events in partnership with LGBT Great this year, one session delivered to all Network members on how to run an effective employee Network, and one on intersectionality. Our session on intersectionality included a panel of Jupiter employees, including Kiran Nandra, Head of Equities (ExCo member), and was attended by over 100 employees. In 2023, Claire Mediene also hosted a session on Allyship for Jupiter colleagues with Interinvest. Jupiter sponsored and hosted an Interinvest panel on bi-visibility in 2023, including external attendees in Jupiter’s offices and more recently promoted the event with Interinvest with the Charity ‘Just Like Us’. All LGBT Great and Interinvest events are open to Jupiter employees. Our new Jupiter intranet allows for better visibility for such events.
column22: David Bone and Claire Mediene are currently listed as LGBT role models. David Bone and Claire Mediene received Jupiter Proud awards in 2023, a prominent recognition award at Jupiter, for their contributions to the Pride Network and the wider DE&I agenda at Jupiter. Following Claire Mediene's recent nomination as a top 100 Gamechanger, we have been coordinating with our Social Media team to get this published on Linkedin. Our annual Pride party is an opportunity for all Jupiter colleagues to come together and celebrate our LGBT colleagues and allies. This is a very prominent event which is given additional budget (beyond the usual Network budget) and is well attended across the firm.
column25: For each of the selected options in Q3, please describe how your LGBTQ+ DE&I strategy addresses each option.
column26: Notable actions from the wider DE&I Strategy include: Engaging with a third-party consultancy ‘Tall Wall’ to conduct a qualitative review of the experience of Jupiter by underrepresented groups A wider focus on allyship Enhancing line manager and all staff training to promote inclusion and equitable outcomes, for example with the training run by LGBT Great on intersectional allyship in 2024. Enhancing Jupiter’s employer brand external to increase talent attraction from diverse groups. Monitoring of inclusion scores across diversity strands
column29: If yes, please provide details of the process and which stakeholder is accountable for it? Please ensure that you have the permission of the person referenced to use their name.
column30: Annabelle Wood (Head of HR Strategy and Operations) and Tracey Kinsella (HR Director) are accountable for the DE&I Strategy. The efficacy of the DE&I Strategy is measured through: Feedback from the Pride Network on all significant actions from DEI Strategy (presenting to the DE&I Forum) Monitoring of inclusion scores Tracking diversity metrics across the firm In 2025, we intend to enhance our promotions process and tracking to be able to monitor outcomes for diverse groups better within Jupiter. This is based on the qualitative review of the experiences of diverse talent that we conducted with Tall Wall.

column45: How does your organisation utilise sexual orientation and gender identity diversity data to improve LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column46: We use the data to monitor demographic shifts at Jupiter. By collecting gender identity data, we demonstrate to employees that we are an inclusive employer. We anticipate publishing both legal gender and gender identity data externally (today we publish legal gender in our annual report) provided that we can maintain the anonymity of individuals.
column49: What campaigns, strategies or approaches has your organisation undertaken to improve comfort around disclosing self-ID DE&I data?
column50: We have seen a 3-4% improvement in disclosure against both sexual orientation and gender identity. In 2023, we began collecting this data for the first time and undertook a communications campaign to encourage individuals to disclose at the time. We have not made specific efforts to increase this this year, but we are pleased to see an incremental increase in the rate of disclosure despite not pushing this topic. We believe that our broad and visible efforts on inclusion contribute to this shift.
column53: How does your organisation target and attract LGBTQ+ talent?

column5: For each of the selected answers in Q1, please describe what responsibilities they have for LGBTQ+ DE&I in your organisation.
column6: All of our people are responsible for inclusion within the organisation. Our DEI strategy is ultimately the responsibility of our Board with LCP’s CEO as executive responsible for DEI outcomes. The strategy is overseen by a DEI Committee which includes LCP’s Head of People, Head of HR, our DEI manager, another senior partner, and a senior representative from each of our four DEI networks. There is no single area of responsibility as it is central to our entire culture and people principles. The LCP Board, with the support of the DEI Committee, regularly reviews our overall DEI strategy, long-term objectives, DEI purpose and vision and supports the Networks, including the LGBTQ+ Network, to articulate their long-term aims and objectives. To support this strategy, the DEI Committee sets overarching areas of focus and success criteria each year with input from the Networks and stakeholders across LCP and each of the four DEI Networks (LGBTQ+, Women’s, Wellbeing, Multicultural) also agree individual success criteria each year. Progress is regularly reviewed by the DEI Committee to reflect on progress over the year and agree next steps. The current overarching aims and long-term objectives for the LGBTQ+ network are below: • Provide a welcoming and inclusive environment for LCPers who identify as LGBTQ+ o Run a series of socials and events o Drive attendance at regular coffee mornings o Work with HR to understand whether LGBTQ+ colleagues are overrepresented in leavers from LCP • Have an influence outside our network by raising awareness, being visible, and supporting our wider community o Increase visibility by posting on Viva Engage o Use events and other means to raise money for our nominated charities, where relevant and appropriate to do so • Promote LCP externally as an LGBTQ+ inclusive employer, expanding and deepening LCP’s connections with clients, peers and industry groups. o Build on success of last year’s client event o Continue to support industry groups such as O:Pen, LINK, and TIDE o Build connections with LGBTQ+ individuals as clients and firms who refer us work. Examples of the success criteria against these objectives specific to this year include: • Running at least three socials / events, with at least one to have a trans awareness focus • Work with other networks to deliver intersectional events (eg book or film clubs, or a panel event) • Target average attendance at coffee mornings of 10+ people • A fundraising target of £1,500 for the year plus matching from the LCP Foundation • Target 120+ attendees with similarly positive feedback for an annual client event • Utilise LGBT Great training credit
column9: For each of the selected stakeholder groups in Q3, please describe who they are and how they are measured against LGBTQ+ DE&I goals and objectives. Please confirm that you have the permission of the person referenced to use their name.
column10: Individuals will be measured against their own personal objectives each year at their annual appraisal. Qualitative feedback will be gathered and collated from all stakeholders. Any quantitative objective, e.g., “organise two external networking events for the LGBTQ network and allies” or “attend at least [X] LGBTQ+ events during the year” will be measured as such.
column13: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column14: Performance against objectives is measured at annual appraisals, and feeds into bonus and pay review consideration. There is a large degree of discretion to annual bonuses, and therefore significant efforts to supporting DEI causes can be rewarded. Time spent on LGBTQ+ inclusion activities, or on wider DEI leadership, is considering “productive time” when it comes to reviewing hours charged as part of year end appraisals. In addition our employee recognition awards include an award category focussed on those making an impact in the DEI and within the broader CSR space. Individuals are nominated by other colleagues for the work and effort they put in with those with significant achievements being fully recognised across the business for their contribution.
column17: For each of the selected responses in Q7, please describe what proactive actions have been taken in the last 12 months by individuals and the organisation.
column18: Mentoring and Reverse mentoring Mandatory firm-wide training on DEI for new joiners Training for our Partner Champions and Active Allies Participation in LGBT Great’s mentoring programme Participation and leadership of O:Pen, the LGBTQ+ Network for the pensions industry. Participation and leadership of LINK, the LGBTQ+ Network for the insurance industry. Attendance at city parent, LGBT Great, O:Pen, and diversity project events and webinars. Attendance of two LGBTQ+ network members at the Stonewall employers conference A DEI session for those recently promoted to partner, including LGBTQ+ case studies Networking opportunities including film nights, coffee mornings and client events Reporting to the LCP Board on the latest diversity metrics, objectives and activities of the LGBTQ+ Network
column25: For each of the selected options in Q3, please describe how your LGBTQ+ DE&I strategy addresses each option.
column26: All supplier onboarding includes a questionnaire on their inclusion policies. Exit interviews include specific questions around inclusion and any issues around an individual’s experience in the organisation. There is specific mandatory training, awareness raising, and education around LGBTQ+ issues for all. Our LGBTQ+ network is actively promoted in our recruitment process and heavily advertised to new joiners, including a training and welcome DEI lunch for our annual graduate intake. We are now gathering diversity characteristics of applicants so that we can measure, monitor and report on representation and trends within our talent pipeline to be able to identify and mitigate any barriers to inclusion. We continually review our recruitment approach, including using contextualised grading and third parties where appropriate to promote equity and reduce the impact of bias.

column30: Regular DEI surveys are carried out including questions specific to LGBTQ+ inclusion. Collated results and themes are shared with the LGBTQ+ network, and overall results and themes are shared across the business. We have implemented a series of data collection processes across the employee experience to be able to better monitor and track the impact of our strategy. The DEI survey is the responsibility of the DEI Committee and is driven by Zoe Burdo, Partner and DEI manager, and Jill Ampleford, Senior Partner and DEI Lead. The next survey is scheduled for 2025. In the meantime our broader colleague engagement survey is scheduled for the end of 2024.

This covers transitioning at work, non-binary people, issues such as dress codes and changes to HR records. Our parental leave policy includes adoption and is fully inclusive of LGBTQ+ families. Copies attached above.

column49: What campaigns, strategies or approaches has your organisation undertaken to improve comfort around disclosing self-ID DE&I data?
column50: Over 2023, we ran a specific communications programme with senior leaders across the firm sharing stories to encourage colleagues to submit diversity data. The focus was on making all colleagues feel comfortable and confident that their data would be secure and used in an appropriate way. We signpost to data collection as part of our standard onboarding process for new joiners, and regularly encourage engagement with the campaign in most firm-wide updates and training sessions.
column53: How does your organisation target and attract LGBTQ+ talent?
column54: We publicise our diversity, equity and inclusion work and initiatives, emphasise how this fits in with our culture and also seek feedback from applicants on whether they have been drawn to us because of our efforts in this area. We run Life At LCP Instagram and Linked In accounts to be able to more freely share our less formal initiatives and practices. We are actively ensuring applicants are aware we are inclusive. Over the last year we have (and continue to) make use of the LGBT Great jobs board to advertise our vacancies. We are a member of the diversity project, LGBT Great, Link and are a founding member of O:Pen. This allows us to actively raise awareness and develop an LGBTQ+ employer brand. We have a number of openly LGBTQ+ senior colleagues, who are celebrated openly on our social media. We include DEI as a priority in all of our recruitment events, be that university fairs or careers fairs. Our networks feature heavily in new business pitches.
column57: How does your organisation seek to position itself as an LGBTQ+ inclusive employer?
column58: Through our policies, procedures, press releases, recruitment initiatives, our advocacy work, our support of LGBTQ+ charities, publicity in new business responses and presentations, highlighting our work at conferences and events, and inviting clients to our DEI Network events. We also work with our clients to improve their own DEI practices and governance. We host a large annual client event to celebrate Pride month and ensure that this is widely advertised to clients, mutual advisers within the industry, and to potential recruits. We advertise ourselves as an LGBTQ+ inclusive employer on our “Life at LCP” Instagram page, which we use to celebrate our various DEI initiatives and events. We also have a dedicated space on our recruitment website to show our commitment to DEI and the work that our networks do. We signpost our DEI commitment and provide briefing on our networks and initiatives to recruitment agencies so that they are able to speak to candidates about what we do in this area.
column61: If yes, please name the policy and/or actions that your organisation is taking to reduce bias in the recruitment process and support for line managers.
column62: All involved in the recruitment process are provided with unconscious bias training. Those who interview also receive further training sessions. The significant majority of our early careers recruitment is initially screened by a third party partner based on pre-agreed criteria. Data supplied by applicants as part of our DEI data collection process (including sexual orientation for example) is not shared with recruiting managers or those interviewing. Additionally, all partners, people managers, and people leaders have received trans-awareness training.

column66: All of the above areas are under a consistent, rolling review between HR, recruitment, and the DEI Networks. All of the areas above have been reviewed to ensure our culture is heavily promoted and interns are given the opportunity to participate in the LGBTQ+ network for the period they are with us. Many interns later come back to LCP in permanent graduate roles.

column114: For Coming Out Day, LCP colleagues from across the business have generously shared their personal coming out stories. Coming out stories were part of a campaign, printed on specially designed postcards and distributed in our offices. The postcards also contain information on the importance of Coming Out Day, and on the work that AKT does, alongside a donation link. These stories help raise awareness and enable all colleagues taking part to become visible role models. We also nominate LCP colleagues for LGBT Great’s Gamechangers Awards. In 2023, 2 LCP employees were featured as part of the Top50.

column118: Our dress code is 'dress for your day', with the following specification: "Our goal is to create an inclusive environment for all and we embrace our people wearing clothing, hairstyles and accessories that reflect their preferred gender expression, culture, ethnicity and/or religion (for example a sari, braids or dreadlocks would be suitable for a client meeting)."
